items.title: Lean UX: A History
items.content:
Understanding the need for Lean UX

To understand why the Lean UX framework is needed, it’s helpful to understand the history of UX design prior to Lean working methods.

Waterfall UX

Prior to 2013, UX teams tended to rely upon the waterfall method, in which one stage of the design process is completed and signed off upon before the next stage can begin.

The steps of the waterfall method might look something like this:

  1. Conduct discovery research
  2. Create deliverables aimed at understanding user motivations (personas, task flows, journey maps)
  3. Use ideation techniques to generate ideas
  4. Create medium-fidelity wireframes
  5. Transform the wireframe into a mockup by adding high-fidelity details
  6. Develop the high-fidelity design into a working product
  7. Launch the product
  8. Gather user feedback on the live product, and repeat the process

Each deliverable in the waterfall method is handed off to another team when completed, which is part of the problem. The waterfall method limits communication between teams during the design process, and it often leads to development teams sitting idle, waiting for a design to receive approval before they can begin building it.

Additionally, the waterfall method offers few opportunities to seek feedback from actual users. The design and development teams might spend months building a feature, only to discover upon launch that nobody needs it.

Waterfall UX is incompatible with Agile development

In addition to being slow to execute, limiting communication between teams, and minimizing opportunities for user feedback, waterfall UX has an additional issue: it doesn’t mesh with the way developers work.

In 2001, a group of 17 developers released the Manifesto for Agile Software Development, emphasizing the following values:

  • Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
  • Working software over comprehensive documentation
  • Customer collaboration over contract negotiation
  • Responding to change over following a plan

Essentially, in the Agile methodology developers work in short sprints of predefined lengths, typically 1 to 4 weeks. By setting modest short-term goals and testing changes and seeking feedback frequently, developers are able to adapt to changes quickly. Rather than working towards one massive product launch, Agile developers produce work in small, testable increments.

While there is debate in design communities about whether Agile methodologies can be used as is by designers, a Lean approach allows designers to break from the slower waterfall method and work in a style that better aligns with modern development practices.

Introducing Lean UX

In 2013 an organizational designer and UX team leader named Jeff Gothelf introduced Lean UX in Lean UX: Designing Great Products with Agile Teams, a book written in response to pain points his design team experienced using the waterfall method.

The Lean UX methodology emphasizes three principles:

  • Removing waste. Lean UX cuts down on the number of design deliverables and the amount of documentation created in favor of Minimum Viable Products (MVPs) that can be tested quickly by users.
  • Constant collaboration. Lean UX relies on a concept called “radical transparency”. Teammates such as developers, product managers, quality assurance engineers, and marketers partner frequently with designers. Each team communicates their findings early and often.
  • More experimentation. By emphasizing testable hypotheses rather than strict project requirements, designers are free to test out rapid experiments, while discarding invalidated assumptions.
“(Adopting a Lean mindset) requires an organization-wide position of humility. It requires teams and managers to use their knowledge and skills and creativity as scientists might: they propose their best solution and then they test to see if they’re right.” – Jeff Gothelf, Lean UX: Designing Great Products with Agile Teams

items.title: Working with Lean UX
items.content:
What is an MVP?

The Minimum Viable Product, or MVP, is both central to the Lean UX approach and key to understanding the Lean process. The term actually predates Lean UX: Eric Ries, author of the influential 2011 business strategy book Lean Startup, defines MVP this way:

The minimum viable product is that version of a new product which allows a team to collect the maximum amount of validated learning about customers with the least effort.

By definition, creating an MVP shouldn’t take a lot of work. In fact, the goal of creating an MVP is to spend the least amount of effort possible to initiate the next round of gathering feedback from users. Lean UX is designed to minimize wasted effort, and the sooner you find out whether an idea is worth pursuing, the less effort your team will invest in it.

An MVP can be small: a landing page, a subtle design variation, a paper prototype. The design team should be constantly asking what is the most important thing we need to learn next? and design the MVP towards answering that question.

The Lean UX Process

The Lean UX process consists of four stages:

  1. Outcomes, assumptions, hypotheses
  2. Design
  3. Creating the MVP
  4. Research and Learning

Note that the four stages form a cycle. Once your team has learned from the previous cycle, it’s time to take those learnings and form a new hypothesis to inform your next round of designs.

Outcomes, assumptions, and hypotheses

In his book Lean UX, author Jeff Gothelf titles a chapter “Assumptions are the New Requirements”. In other words, a list of requirements at the beginning of a design project can lead to problems, since predetermined requirements assume we know exactly what we need to build.

Instead, Gothelf proposes a less rigid start to a project: testable assumptions based on what your team knows thus far about your target users, and focused on how the outcomes of the product might benefit the user.

Testable assumptions are then used to craft a hypothesis meant to inform research and testing. Gothelf provides the following template for writing a hypothesis:

We believe we will achieve (this business outcome)

If (these personas)

Attain (this benefit or user outcome)

With (this feature or solution)

An effective hypothesis begins with the words “we believe” to clarify that these are educated guesses. We don’t know this, but we’re planning to research and test the idea. The hypothesis should have a clear target user who gets an obvious benefit from the feature, and the feature should help solve a business problem.

Design

To test your hypotheses, sometimes you’ll conduct research. Other times, you’ll need to design and build something. For example, if your hypothesis involves the percent of users willing to sign up for a service, you might create a landing page and a sign up form. But rather than jumping right in to a higher-fidelity stage, the Lean UX design process starts with a collaborative design sprint.

While the Lean UX sprints are still led by designers, design sessions should involve participation from a variety of teammates across departments. Getting feedback early from developers, quality assurance engineers, and marketers can reveal obvious usability issues before even testing designs.

Collaborative design sprints should be conducted using low-fidelity methods. This allows participation from everyone regardless of drawing skills, and allows design teams to quickly pivot away from failed approaches.

Creating the MVP

The MVP might take the form of a sketch, a medium-fidelity wireframe, a high-fidelity mockup, a prototype. The level of polish you’ll apply to your MVP should reflect your hypothesis. If color choice, typography, imagery, and iconography aren’t particularly relevant to your hypothesis, or the type of feedback you’re seeking, there’s no need to spend time creating a high-fidelity mockup at the MVP stage.

When in doubt, refer back to Eric Ries’s definition of an MVP: you're looking for the maximum amount of validated learnings about users with the least amount of effort.

Research and Learning

One of the key principles of Lean UX is embracing continuous discovery. Design teams need to continuously engage with users during the design and development process to understand both what the user is doing with and MVP and why they’re doing it.

Lean UX research should be quick and frequent, and executing it requires “getting out of the building”–in other words, observing users in their own context, rather than in a conference room or formal setting.

And just as Lean UX design sprints are conducted collaboratively, the process of validating each hypothesis should be conducted with a variety of teams represented.

items.title: 🎬 Lean UX | The Waterfall Method
items.content:
Transcript

Hello. My name is Anwar and I'm part of the Product Design curriculum team here at Flatiron School. In this series of lectures, we'll be discussing Lean UX. The topics we'll be covering include defining the waterfall method and listing reasons to avoid it, introducing Lean UX practices, understanding what it means to create a minimum viable product or MVP, and the role user stories serve when practicing Lean UX. 

Let's start with the waterfall method. 

Commonly practiced by design teams prior to 2013, the waterfall method focuses on the execution of completed deliverables. In the waterfall method, each individual design deliverable needs to be signed off upon completion, then handed off to the next team. 

When using the waterfall method, design and development teams could sink months into creating products and features before receiving user feedback. If users didn't need that product or feature those months were wasted. 

If designers work to thoroughly complete a high resolution prototype before handing it off to developers, it means developers lack opportunities to provide feedback during the design process. The waterfall method also sometimes leaves teams sitting idle, waiting for the previous deliverable to receive sign-off. 

In 2001, a group of developers released the Manifesto for Agile Software Development, calling for developers to move away from working towards a single massive product launch in favor of short sprints with modest short-term goals. Working in short sprints, followed by testing, allows developers to make adjustments when something isn't working. 

By 2013 designers realized they needed a new method of working to keep pace with developers and encourage more frequent communication between teams and with target users. 

Now it's time for discussion.

  1. What inefficiencies with the waterfall method make it incompatible with Agile development methods?
  2. What opportunities do you see to improve the waterfall design method?

items.title: 🎬 Lean UX | Introducing Lean UX
items.content:
Transcript

So what is Lean UX? 

Lean UX was introduced in a 2013 textbook by Jeff Gothelf. The Lean UX design approach created by Gothelf combines principles of user experience design with Agile development methods and Lean Startup techniques. When I say Lean Startup, I'm referring to an influential 2011 business textbook by Eric Ries called The Lean Startup that emphasizes reducing waste by increasing the frequency of contact with real customers using rapid prototyping methods. 

Lean UX prizes cross-functional teams, meaning teams don't work in isolation, but instead learn from each other. Visual design, software engineering, product management, interaction design, content strategy, marketing, and quality assurance teams share information and see problems from different points of view. 

Lean UX teams have permission to fail, meaning it's not necessary to thoroughly complete research projects before creating designs. Instead, teams make assumptions based on what they currently know about their audience. Using that assumption, teams form a hypothesis about how a particular solution might impact user and business outcomes and create a testable design iteration. That testable design iteration is known as a minimum viable product or MVP. We'll take a closer look at MVPs before long. 

Lean UX methods encourage continuous discovery. Every time a testable iteration or MVP gets created, design teams put it in front of target users and discover how they respond. Get out of the building means that Lean UX prizes contextual inquiry. Observe users in their natural environment as much as possible. 

Lean UX removes much of the waste created by the waterfall method. By testing your work frequently, you can identify usability problems, discard invalidated hypotheses, and stop working on features users don't need.

items.title: 🎬 Lean UX | Minimum Viable Product (MVP)
items.content:
Transcript

Now let's take a look at minimum viable products. Minimum viable products are central to the Lean UX cycle, which consists of Think, Make, Check. In the Think stage, design teams think of a new hypothesis based on assumptions made about the needs and behaviors of the target audience. In the Make stage, design teams create an MVP to place in front of target users during the Check stage. Designers then take what they've learned and repeat the process.

You shouldn't be spending any more time making things than thinking or checking. Building an MVP means doing just enough work to test your hypothesis with users. In his book The Lean Startup, author Eric Ries defines MVP as that version of a new product which allows a team to collect the maximum amount of validated learning about customers with the least effort. Note the emphasis on "least effort." Doing as little work as possible isn't lazy. It's lean. The faster you find out whether your hypothesis is worth pursuing, the less you invest in it.

This makes changing directions much easier, which increases the agility of your team. MVPs can vary in fidelity depending on the stage of your project and what exactly you're hoping to learn about your users. If color, typeface choice, iconography, and imagery are central to the question you're asking, a high fidelity MVP may be appropriate.

Otherwise, work with the lowest fidelity MVP possible. Remember, the sooner you can place your MVP in front of target users, the sooner you'll know whether your idea is something you should continue working on. Low fidelity methods like paper prototypes are the most efficient way to explore concepts quickly and discard unusable ideas.

Digital wireframes take longer to create than paper prototypes, but they require less imagination from users when it comes to their functionality. Wireframe prototypes are also generally easier to test remotely than paper prototypes. A landing page is a single webpage that appears in response to clicking a marketing promotion, a marketing email, or an online advertisement. Landing pages present information relevant to the viewer and a clear call to action. Landing pages can make effective MVPs because you don't have to create the rest of the website to gauge interest in your idea. Creating a simple landing page for a non-existent product can generate feedback and measure user enthusiasm.

Now it's time for discussion.

  1. What kind of conversation should determine what an MVP looks like?
  2. Who should be present at that conversation?
  3. Can you think of any situations where an MVP might take another form other than the methods discussed in this lecture?

items.title: 🎬 Lean UX | User Stories
items.content:
Transcript

Finally, let's examine the role User Stories play in the Lean UX methodology. 

User Stories are not project requirements or lists of features. They're end goals expressed from a user's perspective. What value does your current solution offer the user? 

User Stories keep teams focused on solving real problems faced by users and keep the whole team moving towards a common goal. Working with User Stories rather than project requirements encourages teams to test out creative solutions. And breaking a project into short sprints with modest goals provides many small victories and drives momentum. 

When thinking about how to format User Stories, start with a persona. In other words, you should have a solid idea of who you're building this product for. The task or action describes what the user is trying to achieve. The description should avoid mentioning the user interface or any specific features someone might use when performing the action. 

The objective or purpose explains the larger problem that needs solving. What is the overall benefit of completing this task or action? 

Here's an example of a User Story. Notice that it lists who the user is, what they want, and why they want it, without specifying how a user interface helps the user solve their problem. Keeping User Stories simple and concrete helps keep a project user- centered and goal- focused and helps limit the scope of an MVP to a particular task.

items.title: Project Brief: Better School Choice
items.content:
Introduction

In Phase 4, you’ll work on one continuous project throughout the phase. The project will teach you how to make sense of unstructured research data. You’ll analyze user transcripts and then complete a synthesis session to identify insights and areas of opportunity. The outcome of this research will support the launch of a new product that helps parents make the best choice when faced with a big decision about school.

Background

The client has tasked you with helping them understand how parents decide where to send their children to school.

Data

The client has access to a wide variety of data pertaining to both public and private schools. However, the client is unsure whether the data is relevant to parents when choosing schools.

For this project, you might consider including all, some, or none of the following data:

  • Classroom size
  • Student test scores
  • Graduation rate
  • Subjects taught
  • Availability of advanced courses
  • Extracurricular activities
  • Diversity
  • Student safety
  • Disability accommodations
  • Facilities and services
  • Access to transportation
  • Tuition

Interview Transcripts

You have inherited interview transcripts from conversations with several parents. Read the following interview transcripts from OurKids.

  • Interview 1
  • Interview 2
  • Interview 3
  • Interview 4
  • Interview 5
  • Interview 6

Research questions

These questions are not meant to constrain the analysis but rather help with the general thematic inquiry into the data. These are not the only topics of interest. The collected research data should inform the synthesis and problem framing.

  • What feelings, inner reasoning, guiding principles, and purposes do parents have when choosing a school for their child?
  • What are some common thinking styles parents demonstrate when making a school choice?
  • How much time do parents typically spend researching different schools? How many schools do they consider before making a choice?
  • What would parents change about the school choice process?

Outcomes

The client has specified three desired outcomes, to be executed in three design sprints.

  • Research: the first sprint consists of analyzing and synthesizing user research, conducting a competitive analysis, and creating job stories and prioritizing features in advance of any visual design exploration.
  • Testing and Iteration: the second sprint consists of designing a plan for usability testing, creating low-fidelity prototypes for conducting tests, iterating based on user feedback, and creating an evaluation report summarizing the results of the usability tests.
  • Final presentation: the third sprint consists of applying design styles to create a high-fidelity prototype, annotating the prototype to provide context, and presenting your design work along with insights and recommendations for next steps to stakeholders.

items.title: The JTBD framework
items.content:
Background

Jobs to be Done (JTBD) is a popular framework with product managers who use it to plan and execute roadmaps, often quarterly. It was invented by Clayton Christensen, an innovation thought leader.

The idea behind the Jobs to be Done framework is that whenever users “hire” (use) a product, they do it to perform a specific “job” (achieve a particular outcome). Product design teams can build more useful products if we can understand the desires that make jobs meaningful.

“People don’t want to buy a quarter-inch drill. They want a quarter-inch hole!” – Theodore Levitt, Harvard Business School

To illustrate the value of Jobs to Be Done, Christensen tells the story of “hiring a milkshake”. A fast-food company attempted to increase its milkshake shares by asking target users to list the characteristics of an ideal milkshake, then altering the recipe based on the feedback. However, sales did not improve.

Christensen spent time observing customers who bought milkshakes and discovered that 40 percent were sold first thing in the morning by commuters who purchased them to go.

He then interviewed this specific group of customers, and determined they faced all of the following:

  • A specific problem: a long, boring commute.
  • A specific need: a midmorning snack that would keep them full until lunch.
  • Specific constraints: they were in a hurry, wearing work clothes, and had only one free hand.

By understanding the jobs commuters “hired” milkshakes to do, they responded with a thicker milkshake that could last through a long commute–one with more interesting ingredients (such as chunks of fruit) for a dull morning routine.

Components of Jobs to be Done

Everything in the JTBD framework comes from or is informed by research. JTBD is all about understanding and designing for customer needs while considering who, what, how, why, and when/where.

  1. Job statements
  2. Job performer
  3. Outcome statements
  4. Job map

Job statements

Jobs are what the user wants to accomplish.

  • A job is stable and does not change over time.
  • Jobs don't have geographical boundaries.
  • A job is solution agnostic.

Core jobs are the overarching aim of the user. All other jobs are defined relative to the Core job. “Get my groceries for the week” or “Decide what school my child will attend” are examples of core jobs.

Related jobs help you understand other objectives that might support the main job. “Buy only organic, local fruits and vegetables” is a related job to the grocery example. “Feel like my child is safe while at school” is a related emotional job to the school example.

Emotional jobs define how customers want to feel or avoid feeling as a result of executing the core functional job.

Social jobs define how the customer wants to be perceived by others.

Job performer

The job performer is who executes the job.

Goal-based personas are particularly valuable because they focus on behavior patterns in the problem space, not the solution itself.

Outcome statements

Outcomes are how the user measures success.

A customer's desired outcomes don't change over time, only the solutions do. This is part of why JTBD can be such a useful framework. Outcomes answer the question: Why does the performer strive to complete the job?

Job map

The job map is the artifact that shows all the steps in getting a job done from the customer’s perspective.

A job map is different from a customer journey map in that it documents the user’s needs and behaviors in a way that does not include your existing (or future) solution. A job map visualizes a linear sequence of discrete stages consisting of smaller goals as the customer progresses toward the main goal, the core functional job. It doesn't show what the customer is doing (solution space), it visualizes what the customer is trying to get done (problem space).

The job map is focused on the underlying goals of the actions being taken. Because of that focus, the job description must be independent of any and all competing solutions the customer is using. It is the ideal process flow for that job, including all the steps in the right order for job completion or attainment.

Note: Jobs to Be Done is a comprehensive product development framework that can define a company's strategy and roadmap for a year. There are several other parts of JTBD that we won't go into during this course. We have selected the methods from JTBD that a product designer is most likely to use and benefit from.

items.title: Job and Outcome Statements
items.content:
Job statements

Job statements are clear (no compound concepts) and do not contain preferences, observations, or techniques. “Quickly find the cheapest vacation package using my phone” is incorrect. “Quickly” and “cheapest” are needs, which are dealt with separately. “Using my phone” is a specific technology. The correct job statement would be “Go on vacation.”

Since jobs don’t rely on a particular solution or technology a useful rubric for job statements is to ask: Would someone have been doing this 50 or 100 years ago?

To write a job statement, follow this simple pattern.

verb + object + clarifier

  • Stay informed about my boarded pet.
  • Establish a retirement portfolio.
  • Improve my health and appearance by running regularly.

Outcome statements

Outcome statements are related to getting the main job accomplished and provide a way to establish success criteria. From the user’s point of view, a need related to the main job “Go on vacation,” might be “Minimize the time it takes to share memories with my family and friends.”

To write an outcome statement, follow this pattern.

direction of change + unit of measurement + object + clarifier

Here is how the example outcome statement breaks down with the pattern.

direction of change (minimize) + unit of measurement (time) + object (share memories) + clarifier (with friends and family).

More examples:

  • Increase the chance that everyone participates in the collaboration.
  • Reduce the chance that someone gets lost.
  • Maximize my ability to integrate outcomes into existing documents.

Circumstances

Circumstances take into account the relevant contextual (when/where) that add meaning to the job. It makes it more precise. For the job “Go on vacation,” a circumstance to consider could be “when I only have three days” or “when I’m with my family.”

items.title: Job Maps
items.content:
The role of the job map in product development

A job map is a visual depiction of the core functional job, deconstructed into its discrete process or job steps, which explains step-by-step exactly what the customer is trying to get done.

A job map does not show what the customer is doing (a solution view); rather, it describes what the customer is trying to get done (a needs view).

– Tony Ulwick, Mapping the Job-to-be-Done

Job maps represent the long-term strategy and vision of a business. Once a job map is finished, you should be able to see deficiencies in the current product or solution. It might be that a certain customer segment has been overlooked, or the product only gets the customer 70% to completing their job.

By mapping everything out, a team is able to prioritize the essential jobs and then think through what must be done to support those jobs. By putting it all in one place, the team can find unmet needs and diverge on solutions to address them. The map also gives teams a way to compare competing solutions.

The stages of a job map

A job is composed of a sequence of chronological stages. These are smaller jobs within the main job and make up a beginning, middle, and end. The stages of the main job “Go on vacation” might be:

  • Beginning
    • Plan
    • Select
    • Prepare
  • Middle
    • Begin vacation
    • Make memories
    • End vacation
  • End
    • Return
    • Reflect
    • Share

Each stage breaks down into steps

Within each stage are discrete steps, the smallest unit in the framework. If we add steps to the Beginning stage, it might look like this:

  • Beginning
    • Plan
      • Budget
      • Find dates
      • Explore vacation packages
    • Select
      • Determine package
      • Share package information
    • Prepare
      • Arrange pickup to travel to the airport
      • Arrive and board

items.title: Writing Job Stories
items.content:
Job stories vs. user stories

A crucial aspect of modern Agile software development is the ability to break down work into individual units. Product managers sometimes write user stories which are short descriptions of functionality written from the user's perspective:

As a (user), I can (capability) so that (benefit).

One critique of user stories is that they are typically derived from the capability being built, not from observed user behavior. Job stories shift emphasis from who is doing a story to when and why the story is happening, and do a better job contextualizing the user need.

“We frame every design problem in a Job, focusing on the triggering event or situation, the motivation and goal, and the intended outcome.

When ______, I want to ______, so I can ______.

For example: When an important new customer signs up, I want to be notified, so I can start a conversation with them.”

– Paul Adams, The Dribbblisation of Design

Writing job stories is easier if you've researched and defined all the stages and steps of the core job on a job map. One feature might have three to eight different job stories, and an entire product could have hundreds. It's not necessary to write all the job stories at once, only when a job step or sub-job is ready to be developed.

The job story format

There are variations of the job story format, but the one we recommend is by Jim Kalbach, author of the Jobs to Be Done Playbook:

When I [circumstance + job stage/step], I want to [micro-job], so I can [need].

He offers these examples of job stories.

  • When I am one of the top posters while updating my social media feeds daily, I want to show it on my profile so I can increase recognition as an expert on the subject.
  • When I run out of materials needed while completing an art project, I want to find alternative materials so I can maximize the number of uses of my current supplies.
  • When preparing for my commute and running late, I want to know the current weather along my journey so I can minimize the chance of arriving wet.

Let's break down this last example. The job performer “commuter” is trying to do the core job “commute to work” and finds themselves in the the circumstance/context “running late.” The job stage/step is “When preparing for my commute” and within that stage is a micro-job “check forecast.”

Notice that the statement does not contain any reference to a solution or technology. This same job story could easily apply to someone 20 or even 50 years ago. The need comes from an outcome statement on a job map, “minimize the chance of arriving to work wet.”

Take a few minutes now and practice breaking down the first two examples in a similar manner.

Remember, job stories, just like everything in JTBD, come from research: interviews, observations, focus groups. While each job story is fictional, it is based on an insight that comes from user research.

items.title: 🎬 Jobs to Be Done | Introduction
items.content:
Transcript

Hello. My name is Anwar  and I'm part of the Product Design curriculum team here at  Flatiron School. In this series of lectures, we'll be discussing the Jobs To Be Done framework. Let's start with a discussion question. What would motivate you to buy a drill? 

Maybe some of you would buy one just to have one, just in case, or to have your tool set feel more complete. But most people buy drills when they're looking to build something. In the words of Harvard Business School marketing professor Theodore Levitt, people don't want to buy a quarter inch drill. They want a quarter inch hole. 

In other words, sometimes it's helpful to look beyond the immediate step facing users and see it as part of a larger process for achieving a more meaningful goal. 

In 2017,  Ikea bought TaskRabbit,  one of the best known startups in the gig economy that connects freelance labor with local demand, allowing consumers to find help with everyday tasks. Why did Ikea start offering furniture assembly by TaskRabbit ? Because they recognized that Ikea customers aren't motivated by assembling furniture. 

They want to be organized, express their individuality, and feel comfortable in their home. 

With the Jobs To Be Done framework, we analyze why people hire products, services, software, and ideas, and then discover innovative opportunities to grow. 

The Jobs To Be Done framework helps us identify the outcomes users ultimately hope to accomplish when hiring a product or service. Understanding customer needs from their point of view helps us pinpoint new opportunities. Clayton Christensen, author of the Jobs To Be Done framework, illustrates this with a story he calls "hiring a milkshake". 

By observing customers who bought milkshakes from fast food restaurants, Christiansen discovered many customers wanted a treat they could enjoy one-handed during a long and dull drive to work. Once we recognize what jobs customers ultimately want the milkshakes to fulfill, we can make thicker milkshakes that lasts for a longer portion of the commute. 

So how does one use the Jobs To Be Done framework? The first step is to identify the jobs customers are actually hoping to accomplish. If a customer wants to purchase running shoes, what is the main job to be done? 

If you said to go running regularly, that's not bad, but we might categorize that as a related job to our customer's main job: to get more exercise and get healthy. Knowing that helps us realize that our competition extends beyond direct competitors, like other running shoe brands. Customers could also get more exercise with a bike, or a jump rope, or a set of weights. 

Once we've defined our competition, we can determine our criteria for success. How will we measure how satisfied customers are with our proposed solution? Finally, we'll create desired outcome statements, which provide insight about the things customers value most.

items.title: 🎬 Jobs to Be Done | Identify Job Types
items.content:
Transcript

When using the Jobs To Be Done framework, what process do we use to identify our user's main job? And what other types of supplementary jobs are there? Let's take a look. A job is not what you design. A job is what the job performer wants to get done. So returning to our example of a company selling running shoes, buying shoes isn't our customer's main job.

It's getting more exercise. The customer might have related objectives, such as running a certain distance each week. An emotional job might be to feel pride in meeting those running goals, or to avoid a family history of heart disease. And many jobs have a social component such as bragging about your improved physique on social media. Understanding the main, related, emotional, and social jobs customers want to get done is achieved through qualitative research methods, such as interviews and contextual observation. With the Jobs To Be Done framework, we can start looking for ways to systematically create value. The provided questions can help guide our search and keep us from missing opportunities.

A great way to start is to think about the biggest problems with the current solutions. Can the job be executed in a more efficient or effective way? Do some customers struggle more with executing the job than others? In what contexts do customers most struggle with executing the job? To make our analysis work better, we want a team of experts from different fields like marketing, design, engineering, and even target customers to join this discussion.

items.title: 🎬 Jobs to Be Done | Job Maps
items.content:
Transcript

Let's take a look at the role Job Maps play within the Jobs To Be Done framework. A Job Map is a visual depiction of the customer's main job that explains step by step exactly what they are trying to get done. Mapping out the job enables teams to not only think of what can be done to support the customer's journey, but also identify places where customer needs are overlooked and customers face an unsatisfying experience.

The goal of creating a Job Map is not to find out how the customer actually executes a job, as that only generates maps of existing activities and solutions. Instead, the aim is to discover what the customer is trying to get done at different points in executing a job and what must happen at each step in order for the job to be carried out successfully. The first four steps here–

define the objective, locate and prepare tools for completing the task, and confirm readiness–are preparatory steps a customer takes in order to execute a job. After execution, the customer will monitor the results, make modifications as needed, and conclude the task. A Job Map is not a customer journey, service blueprint, or workflow diagram.

It does not reflect what a person does to discover, learn about, select, buy, and use a product or service. It instead focuses on customer needs and describes what they are trying to get done independent of any specific solution. When companies focus on jobs customers need to get done, they can use Job Maps to break jobs into steps and find innovation opportunities that are the key to growth.

Some of these innovation opportunities can be found by asking meaningful questions while examining each individual step within a Job Map. Do some customers struggle more than others with this step? Is this step more difficult to execute successfully in some contexts than others? What are the biggest drawbacks of current solutions used to execute this step?

items.title: 🎬 Jobs to Be Done | Criteria For Success
items.content:
Transcript

To use the Jobs To Be Done framework effectively, it's critical you establish clear criteria for measuring success. What do customers need when performing a job, and how will you gauge how successful they are at having those needs met? You can measure needs and success rates by using Desired Outcome Statements, which consists of four parts. 

The direction of change starts with a verb showing what the customer hopes to change. The unit of measure, specifies what the customer wants to increase or decrease. The object of the need is the thing being measured or controlled, while the clarifier provides contextual clues to clarify circumstances. 

Suppose your customer wants to attend a conference related to their industry. They're hoping to learn valuable information, share some of that information with coworkers, and network with conference attendees. How can we use Desired Outcome Statements to create measurable success criteria related to their trip to the conference? 

Here we see four examples. Our first Desired Outcome Statement, "increase the likelihood of getting permission from a boss to attend", can be divided into four parts. Increase is a measurable direction of change. If a customer was previously only 50% successful, we can try to improve that number. The likelihood is a measurable rate of success. 

The customer's need is represented by the third part of the outcome statement. They need to get permission. Our outcome statement ends with a clarification. When does the customer need permission? When asking a boss to attend the conference. Our final three Desired Outcome Statements– maximize the ability to remember relevant content from conference presentations, 

minimize the time it takes to summarize conference insights for sharing with colleagues, and maximize the likelihood of networking with thought leaders in the field– all follow the same format. 

Now you give it a try. Imagine you have a customer preparing to cook dinner. See if you can draft at least three measurable Desired Outcome Statements related to this job.

items.title: 🎬 Jobs to Be Done | Deeper Dive
items.content:
Transcript

What else can be done with the Jobs To Be Done framework? 

Different interpretations and implementations of Jobs To Be Done exist, including goal- directed design, activity- centered design, and task analysis. Goal- directed design places heavy emphasis on the end goals users hope to achieve. Activities and tasks are intermediate steps that help someone reach a goal. 

Activity- centered design is a design model that looks how activities in a system lead to results. The focus is not just on the user, but on the whole system. 

Like a customer journey map, a hierarchical task analysis diagram starts with a goal and a scenario and then shows the most critical tasks needed to reach the goal. In user experience, these tasks are called operations. Designers can consider the overall number of tasks, the frequency of a task occurring, 

the cognitive complexity and physical requirements involved in completing a task, and the time each task takes to complete. 

Let's look at a real- life Jobs To Be Done case study. In 2015, the year Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey reassumed  the position of CEO, the company posted a loss of over $500 million. Under Dorsey's leadership, twitter identified that the company had become overly reactive to innovations by tech industry peers. 

They used the Jobs To Be Done framework to focus on just three core customer jobs: keeping up to date on the news, holding conversations, and getting paid. By prioritizing these three tasks users hire Twitter to do and defining measurable outcomes related to those tasks, Twitter's revenue increased to above $4 billion in 2021. 

When implementing the Jobs To Be Done framework, it's worth considering whether the customer's ultimate goal is to complete a straightforward task, or whether the goal is longer- term behavioral change. If the job is to complete a task, we can measure success by the completion of each activity. However, if the goal is long-term behavior change, we measure success in terms of progress towards that goal. If the customer's goal in preparing dinner is motivated by being thoughtful, we can call this a "be" goal, with a customer focus on behavioral change while working towards an ideal self. We interpret this differently than a "do" goal such as preparing dinner to satisfy immediate hunger. 

When we examine "be" goals, note that success isn't dependent on completion of an activity. Even if the dinner you made for a loved one is cooked badly, you might still feel more thoughtful afterwards. You might also switch activities next time by writing a poem or buying flowers. 

"Do" goals and "be" goals are both useful in the design process. Make sure you know which one you are designing for. 

Now it's time for discussion.

  • What is the first thing you do as you begin performing a job?

items.title: Business Goals vs. User Goals
items.content:
Finding the right balance

The core values for UX-driven product design include empathy, ethics, and usability, with the overall goal to enhance user satisfaction. However, to get a seat at the table with the CEOs, product managers, and other top-level executives, you must consider why they hired you.

The value a product designer brings to the business is easily quantifiable with the help of metrics like conversion rates, retention rates, or improving brand perception and whatever else would help the company grow. Another consideration for the business is the tech restraints from the development team and budget and time.

A simple and straightforward price comparison page would most likely save time and unnecessary headaches to the user and increase the conversion rate. In this example, the user needs and business needs align perfectly, and everybody wins.

However, sometimes it's not as simple. You have the find the right balance between advocating for the user while seeking long-term business gains. For example, a user's goal may be to cancel a subscription easily. However, this may negatively affect retention rates for the business and cost them a lot.

A seasoned product designer needs to make it easy enough for users to cancel the subscription while still aiming to maximize the number of users who willingly choose to stay. Designers should make assumptions on how both business and the user experience might get affected and back it by relevant research.

Educate and communicate

As you gain a seat at the table and the business trusts you to make impactful changes, you must remember your ethical obligations and your responsibility towards your user. As an advocate for the user, you can continue to drive value and make meaningful change.

Another part of your role as a product designer is educating and communicating the importance of user-centric design decisions. If you feel constantly pressured to design things that are not compliant with your values, or industry values, consider questioning whether the job is the right fit for you.

items.title: Feature Prioritization
items.content:
Avoiding “featuritis”

The first reason for prioritizing features is avoiding featuritis: Adding excessive features to a product or service such that it becomes less valuable to customers.

We all want to build the cool rocket ship. But we have to be conscious that we’re building what our users need, not the cool thing we want to make for the sake of it.

Every project has resource limitations, including but not limited to time, money, and people. Research and design thinking methods generate a lot of ideas, but you won’t be able to build all of them at once. Even if we could implement every feature, it wouldn’t necessarily result in a usable product.

As a Product Designer, you will not typically be responsible for setting the project priorities by yourself. Instead, you will be working with the product and engineering teams to prioritize features by discovering:

  • which features add the most value to the business
  • which features are most valuable to the user
  • the technical feasibility of features within the timeframe of the project

Prioritization can’t be personal. You’re choosing the RIGHT feature for your company’s strategy and goals. Let’s look at a few different methods for prioritizing features.

Give Users Value, Not Features

Design teams use low-fidelity prototypes to test assumptions about a product’s value to the user. The more features, patterns, and interactions you add, the harder it is to interpret what is providing the most value.

Let’s say you’re testing adding a rating system to your product. You could include the ability to add and edit comments, upvote reviews, add pictures, sort or filter products by review, flag reviews, and on and on. The problem is you don’t even know if users will value a rating system, much less whether they care about adding their pictures.

Following the Pareto Principle (80/20 rule) will guide you to focus most of your effort on the insights and ideas that bring the most significant benefit to the most users.

According to Steven Douglas at Usability Geek, the Pareto Principle suggests that “80% of your users use 20% of your features”. Your initial explorations should focus on features that provide the most value to the 80%.

We leverage divergent thinking and strategy in the solution phase for this reason because without rounds of testing, we don’t know for sure which approach offers the best results for users. The research and synthesis completed prior to testing divergent solutions tells us where to focus the majority of our attention and limited time.

Limit Your Priorities

Having too many priorities during testing can lead to messy and inconclusive results. Go back to your persona or other user models, and speculate about what value you think a feature will deliver, both to the client and the user. Then make a plan to measure whether or not you are right.

You need to have some idea of what success looks like to judge which features are successful.

If you haven’t already created some user models, try making some with your team now. It will likely save time and effort in the long run.

Unless you intend to hand them off to the client, you don’t have to make them look great–they can be internal thinking tools for your team.

Priority Matrix

The priority matrix is a quick and easy way to evaluate many ideas according to two criteria. Usually, this is done with a 2x2 diagram: one axis is Low to High Effort, and the other axis is Low to High Value. Anything that is High Effort and Low Value is eliminated or put in the backlog. Prioritize the Low Effort and High-Value quadrant.

An affinity diagram session should have shed light and in-depth insight into the user’s needs in the identified problem space. Feature prioritization is about making those needs more concrete by giving the team a way to evaluate the value of proposed features. In a sense, you are creating some helpful guidelines for your upcoming brainstorming sessions.

Good designers know when to apply constraints to their process. Even though we use the double diamond model as a rough depiction of the design thinking process, if we were to zoom in, the process of coming up with ideas looks closer to the image below.

items.title: Feature Prioritization Techniques
items.content:
The prioritization problem

Product teams often face a long list of features to implement and usability improvements to make. Even once you’ve validated your hypotheses, synthesized your research data, and made absolutely certain the improvements are needed, there simply isn’t time to solve everything at once.

While holding a vote among team members sounds like the most democratic way to move forward, the reality is everyone on the team might not be equally informed on the background behind each needed improvement. Dot voting, where each team member places a dot next to the feature they’d like to see prioritized, is prone to biases, and the outcome can be influenced by the most senior person in the room.

Below is a partial list of methods that introduce structure to feature prioritization, while attempting to reduce bias and minimize conflict within product teams. It’s worth noting that each method still involves a degree of subjectivity, and should be viewed as a useful tool, not an absolute truth.

The MoSCoW method

The MoSCoW method asks team members to divide proposed new features and potential improvements into four categories: Must have, Should have, Could have, and Won’t have.

  • Must have: items that are absolutely vital.
  • Should have: items that are important but not absolutely mandatory.
  • Could have: items that are not essential, but nice to have.
  • Won’t have: items that offer little value and are not needed.

To calculate a MoSCoW score, teams can use a process similar to dot voting, but instead assign 3 points for each Must have item, 2 points for each Should have item, and 1 point for each Could have item.

The MoSCoW method works best for teams on a tight timeline. And unlike some other prioritization methods, MoSCow doesn’t consider the effort involved in adding the feature. It only asks team members to determine which features are most vital to the success of the project or product.

The RICE method

The RICE method asks team members to consider the impact of new features and product improvements based on four criteria: Reach, Impact, Confidence, and Effort.

  • Reach represents the number or percentage of users impacted by the feature.
  • Impact is the measure of the value added by the new feature. Will this help the company achieve its goals? What about users?
  • Confidence speaks to how much evidence the design team has to evaluate the potential reach and impact of the new feature. It’s hard to be certain a change will be highly beneficial, but if you’ve gathered supporting data and conducted thorough testing, you’ll be feeling more confident.
  • Effort is an estimate of how difficult it will be to implement the feature.

To calculate a RICE score, add up the first 3 values (reach, impact, confidence) and divide by the 4th (effort). Ranking proposed features based on RICE scores helps product teams determine which ones will provide the most value while costing the least amount of effort.

Feasibility, desirability, and viability scorecard

Another method that asks teams to consider the amount of effort involved in implementing a feature is the feasibility, desirability, and viability scorecard.

This prioritization method uses three criteria to rank each feature or potential improvement.

  • Feasability: how easy is it for the development team to implement the feature?
  • Desirability: how much value does the feature provide for users?
  • Viability: how much value does the feature provide for the business?

The feasibility, desirability, and viability score is useful for ranking potential new features only when supplemented by data. The development team should be consulted for realistic feasability estimates, while desirability scores should be informed by surveying and observing target users.

items.title: 🎬 Balancing User Needs and Business Goals | Speak Business
items.content:
Transcript

Hello, my name is Anwar and I'm part of the Product Design curriculum team here at Flatiron School. In this series of lectures, we'll be discussing two topics: balancing user and business goals and feature prioritization.

The content we'll be covering includes why designers need to speak the language of business, how to earn the trust of your stakeholders, and different methods for prioritizing product features. Let's begin with learning to speak business. The first term to discuss is tradeoffs. Designers need to be aware not only of business goals, but also of limitations such as time, budget, and technical capabilities. Tradeoffs happen when striking a balance between factoring in business goals and limitations and creating an optimal user experience. When deciding on tradeoffs, it often helps to create a two dimensional graph with increasing user value on the Y axis and decreasing effort by organization on the X axis.

If a proposed improvement or solution offers high user value and requires low effort to implement, teams should prioritize it. Keep in mind that while a product designer is a built-in advocate for the user, the user doesn't hire the product designer. The business does. You have an equal responsibility to address business objectives.

Any proposed improvement or solution should not only benefit the user, but also meet business goals. The term Product Sweet Spot can be used to describe situations where designers have considered three factors. The first is user needs. What makes the user's ability to complete tasks easier? What makes users feel confident, competent, and in control when using your product?

The second is business needs. How will the business make or save money? How will the business gain new customers or keep existing ones? The third is technical constraints. Do we have sufficient time and budget to implement this feature? Do we have access to the right technology? A product designer who considers all three factors gains respect and earns their seat at the table.

Let's consider a scenario that misses the Product Sweet Spot. Have you ever had trouble canceling a subscription? What was the product? Why was cancellation so difficult? Making it impossible to cancel a subscription is a dark pattern. It benefits the business financially in the short term, and it's probably not hard for developers to build. But doing so is damaging to the brand's image and shatters user trust. Now let's flip the scenario. What if you designed an interface where the cancel button was bold and the first thing users saw on their account page?

Clicking it would cancel user subscriptions without any warning or any chance for the users to change their mind. While this would create a seamless experience for users, and would be easy for developers to implement, the business would likely suffer. Products sometimes need to keep users for a length of time to convince them of the value they provide.

This scenario isn't thinking about the business or the cost of the design decision. Chances are, with metrics showing an uptick in cancellations and revenue going down, this designer would not be hired again. Your job is to create solutions that meet both user and business needs. Is the solution always black and white?

Probably not. You have a responsibility to advocate for the user that isn't in the room, but also for the business that hired you to make a better product.

Now it's time for discussion.

  1. Apart from the cancellation flows we've already discussed, can you think of any features and products you've used that only solve business needs, but don't consider user needs?
  2. What about the reverse? Can you think of product features that benefit users, but increase business costs to maintain?

items.title: 🎬 Balancing User Needs and Business Goals | Earning Stakeholder Trust
items.content:
Transcript

Next, let's talk about earning stakeholder trust. We'll start by defining a variety of stakeholder specializations. A Product Owner is an individual responsible for advocating for stakeholder needs and making sure decisions are made with an eye on maximizing business value. A Project Manager applies project management methodologies and tools to ensure projects deliver the expected results within scope, time, and budget. A Functional or Technical Lead provides input on behalf of the engineering team and assesses the technological feasibility of proposed ideas.

Finally, Subject Matter Experts or SMEs are staff members who exhibit a high level of expertise in a specialized job, task, or skill. Before we go any farther, here's a scenario to imagine. You're in a room full of stakeholders, presenting data in an attempt to convince the team to make a drastic change to the product site map.

What are the chances everyone is following along, understanding your motivations, and agreeing with you?

The truth is no matter how convincing your data, facts alone aren't persuasive. The relationships you build with people in that room will make them trust you and thus your facts. Work on the same team and bring everyone along on the journey. When investing in relationships with stakeholders, here are a few things to keep in mind. Lead with positivity. No one wants to just hear a long list of negatives about their product. Practice empathy. Understand stakeholder perspective, goals, and Key Performance Indicators. Understand where stakeholders are coming from before trying to convince them to change directions.

Be honest and open about progress and leverage stakeholder help to remove blockers. Be proactive. A great product designer looks for opportunities and proposes improvements rather than just following orders. At the same time, here are a few things to avoid. Don't rely on facts alone. Don't be a know-it-all.

Avoid relying on complex terminology and techniques that make you sound impressive and intimidate your audience. Invite stakeholders into the conversation and ask questions to show you're interested in what they have to say. What's on your mind? How did you decide to take that approach? Why is this important to you?

Questions like these are a great way to extend empathy and build trust. Now, here's a workshop scenario for you to practice. Your stakeholders have declared a business goal of limiting customer service requests by requiring users to filter through FAQs before viewing a customer service phone number or submitting a ticket. On the other hand, your users have a goal of contacting support as quickly as possible so they can get their problems solved. What can we design as a possible solution that meets both of these objectives? Pause the video and take 10 to 15 minutes to sketch out a few possible solutions on paper.

All right. How did you do? Let's discuss a sample solution. Pointing users to the right answer in a well-organized FAQ section solves both problems. Users get help faster and the business cuts down on support tickets. To do this, you might implement a system that quickly suggests a few common support answers based on category using either dropdowns or a suggestive search.

items.title: 🎬 Balancing User Needs and Business Goals | Feature Prioritization
items.content:
Transcript

Sometimes design team meetings and meetings with stakeholders can grow argumentative if everyone present has a different idea of what features to prioritize. In the words of UX consultant Paul Boag, it is absolutely crucial to identify what core activities you want to support so that you have a clear picture of what lies outside of that core.

In other words, having a clear set of user and business goals identified will help you identify which features are most critical to achieving those goals. So what should we not be using to drive our feature prioritization decisions?

We shouldn't trust gut reactions. Sometimes people push an agenda because of a recent personal experience or a bit of negative feedback from an investor. While these arguments have a certain emotional appeal, feature prioritization should be backed up by data and user research. As for sales and support requests,

these are the people on the front lines of your company. If they're hearing complaints, they'll tell you. However, don't forget there is a difference between what users say they want and what research demonstrates they actually need. How about the ROI or return on investment from a single feature? While a particular feature may promise more business revenue, more income doesn't always equal a better experience for your users.

What characteristics are common to a positive feature prioritization experience? Transparency means everybody present should be able to see and understand how priorities are set. Consistency means sticking to a feature prioritization method quarter after quarter and not making arbitrary changes.

How about fairness? Stakeholders might feel disappointed when their favorite feature isn't prioritized, but the disappointment is lessened when they perceive that the decision-making process is a fair one. Outcome orientation means we don't just prioritize features individually. Instead we view them holistically, searching for bundles of features that provide measurable value to the user and business. As for speed, it's always important to not only estimate how long a particular feature will take to implement and how much effort it requires from designers and developers, but also to communicate this clearly to stakeholders. Finally, keep all participants engaged by providing them a chance to offer feedback and stay involved and informed.

Let's take a look at a few common feature prioritization methods used in the industry, including the Kano model, the Effort versus Impact matrix, the Eisenhower matrix, the MoSCoW method, and the WSJF method. The Kano model prioritizes features according to two competing criteria: their potential to satisfy customers and the investment needed to implement them.

While the strength of the Kano model is that it approaches feature prioritization from the user's perspective, it can be a bit complex to implement and for team members to understand. The Effort versus Impact Matrix can be a great way to think about the problems users face within your product. The x-axis on this two dimensional matrix is labeled Impact and refers to the value of solving a specific problem.

If the problem isn't a major blocker for users or the solution doesn't offer much value, the impact will be minimal. The y-axis is labeled Effort and represents the amount of labor the solution will take and the feasibility of solving the problem. Former president Dwight Eisenhower is credited with creating a distinction between Important tasks that contribute to long term goals versus Urgent tasks that require immediate action and offer only short term benefits. When using the Eisenhower Matrix, if a task is both important and urgent, you should do it right away.

If a task is important, but not urgent, you should schedule a time to handle it relatively soon. If a task is urgent, but not important, you should delegate it to someone else whenever possible. And if a task is neither urgent nor important, you should delete it from your list of todos. The letters M, S, C, and W in the name of the MoSCoW method

stand for Must have, Should have, Could have, and Won't have. Features in the Must have quadrant of a Moscow matrix are non-negotiable product needs that are mandatory for the team to deliver. Features in the Should have quadrant can add significant value to the product, but are not vital to add.

Features in the Could have quadrant have less impact and are only nice to have. And features in the Won't have quadrant offer little value and could be postponed or eliminated from consideration. The WSJF method uses a math formula to determine an urgency score for each task. To calculate the urgency score, we add up the cost of delay and divide by the size of the job. The cost of delay is found by adding the user business value, the time criticality, and the risk reduction or opportunity enablement score. The user business value looks at how the feature impacts user and business goals. To determine the time criticality, ask yourself, is there a fixed deadline? Might we lose customers if this is not completed in a certain time? As for risk reduction or opportunity enablement, what is the risk if you delay implementing this feature? Will hurrying allow us to seize an opportunity?

Once you've added these three scores and divided by the difficulty of delivering the feature, you have a WSJF priority score. The higher the score, the more important the task is to complete.
