items.title: Mental and Conceptual Models
items.content:
Finding a match

In user experience design, the goal is to find a match between the users’ mental models and the product’s conceptual model to bring about positive and valuable experiences.

Mental models

Mental models are representations of a person’s intuitive understanding of how something functions based on past encounters, exposure to information, and sound judgment or intuitive perceptions (Source UX Matters). Mental models help shape people’s actions and behavior, influence what people pay attention to in complicated situations, and define how people approach and solve problems.

K.J.W. Craik was the first to discuss mental models in his 1943 book, The Nature of Explanation. The book sat dormant until the 1980’s when the term reappeared in two books published with similar titles of Mental Models. Indi Young wrote a book in 2008 also called Mental Models; however, she uses the term differently as she diagrams the behavior of a particular audience doing a series of tasks, and includes their goals and motivations. Underneath this task flow, she describes what the “system” or product will do or be like, to match the user’s task. Young called this entire deliverable a “mental model” while others would call it a User Journey Map or Task Analysis.

Conceptual models

A conceptual model is the actual designs or ideas given to the user through the product’s interface. Someone designed a user interface, and that interface communicates to you the conceptual model of the product.

Task analysis, observational research, data mining, and user interviews are good ways to understand a user’s mental model. Leveraging the thinking aloud method, hearing users verbalize what they think, believe, and predict while using a product during interviews or user testing is a great way to get insights into a user’s mental model.

Bringing the two together

People struggle to use an interface if it doesn’t match their mental model. Usability testing is the method that typically reveals this disconnect. Patterns become patterns when lots of people agree that there is a connection between mental and conceptual models. During a usability test, if users struggle to use common patterns, it is probably because the conceptual model is not a good match for their (correct) mental model.

When a unique pattern is first introduced, it might not match people’s mental models. It takes time for a pattern to become widely adopted and accepted. Just because people struggle initially with a new pattern does not mean that the design has to change. It might be the case that users need to update their mental models to match the new conceptual model. You should only introduce a new conceptual model if it is genuinely required. Standard practices in digital interfaces are embedded in users’ mental models, and mental models are difficult to shift.

items.title: User Psychology and Behavior Change
items.content:
Users want to form positive habits

In past lessons, we’ve talked about manipulative design patterns. Dark patterns are User Interface patterns that trick users into an unwanted action. And addictive products use techniques such as the Hook Model to form unwanted habits in users, such as constantly swiping to refresh an Instagram feed. Ethical designers should be wary of changing user behavior against their wishes.

However, what if a user wants to change their behavior? Think about situations where a user is hoping to form a new habit to make a positive change to their lives:

  • Exercise more frequently
  • Prepare healthier meals
  • Save money towards retirement
  • Learn a new language

To understand how to work with users to create positive behavior change, it’s important to first understand how users’ minds work, and why they form habits in the first place.

How users’ minds are wired

In his book Designing for Behavior Change, author Stephen Wendel examines the limitations of the human brain when making decisions. Since people don’t have unlimited time, attention, or energy to devote to decision-making, our brains economize using techniques like unconscious habits. For example, when shopping for cereals, we assume muted colors and images of nature indicate a healthier choice than a brightly colored box featuring cartoon characters.

Unconscious habits free up our conscious mind to think about other things.

Before considering how your design might meet user goals and change their habits for the better, Wendel recommends considering four important facts about human decision making:

We’re limited.

Our attention is limited. Multitasking is largely a myth; research has repeatedly shown that we can only pay proper attention to one thing at a time.

Our cognitive capacity is limited. Think of Miller’s Law, which states that the average person can only keep around 7 items in their working memory. We also become overwhelmed when offered with too many options at once.

Our memories are limited. We remember events that occur frequently, like eating breakfast, in a stylized format, losing details of individual occurences and remembering a composite of the repeated experience.

We use two types of thinking.

Our brains largely rely on intuitive or reactive thinking, otherwise known as System 1 thinking. System 1 thinking is fast, unconscious, and automatic, and relies on unconscious habits, gut reactions, and what’s known as “satisficing”–that is, accepting an easy, satisfactory solution rather than seeking perfection.

Deliberate or conscious thinking, known as System 2 thinking, is slow, focused, and self aware. System 2 thinking leads to more carefully considered decision-making, but it’s a lot more work for our brains.

We use System 2 thinking when comparing expensive laptops for work. But when choosing a breakfast cereal, System 1 thinking works fine since the consequences of making the wrong decision are fairly minor.

We rely on shortcuts.

Our unconscious minds rely on shortcuts and habits to make rapid decisions and free our conscious minds to handle other tasks.

The shortcuts our minds use when handling daily tasks are also known as heuristics, and include the following:

  • Status quo bias: when in doubt, don’t change anything. Stick to the known or the routine.
  • Descriptive norms: faced with an uncertain situation, look at what other people are doing, and try to do the same.
  • Confirmation bias: look for information that confirms our existing beliefs.
  • Present bias: pay attention to options that benefit us now, even if the long-term impact is negative.
  • Availability heuristic: when things are particularly easy to remember, we believe they are more likely to occur. For example, if a plane crash is dominating news headlines, we tend to think fatal crashes are more common than they actually are.

We rely on habits.

Habits typically consist of three features, sometimes described with the acronym CAR:

  • Cue: something in our environment that triggers a habitual behavior, such as the smell of coffee brewing at my favorite café triggering my desire for a latte.
  • Action: a routine activity central to a habit, such as interrupting my morning walk to purchase a latte.
  • Reward: something good that happens at the end of a routine, such as a latte’s delicious flavor and burst of caffeine.

Interestingly, the mind can continue craving a reward it no longer receives. If I drink a latte every morning, the caffeine will have less and less of an impact each day, but the promise of the reward (even when reduced or absent) can still motivate the habit.

We’re affected by context.

The framing of a choice impacts our decision making, even when there’s no actual difference between the options.

For example, when comparing two brands of mouthwash:

  • Brand A claims to kill 95% of all germs
  • Brand B claims that only 5% of germs survive

Both brands promise equal effectiveness, yet most users would choose Brand A because it highlights a positive outcome. Think of all the germs it killed! Brand B focuses on a negative outcome, highlighting all the germs left over after rinsing.

Designers can change user behavior

By understanding how users make decisions, designers can ethically and thoughtfully design a context that enables users to

  • Make beneficial decisions
  • Form better habits
  • Achieve difficult goals

To do so, designers need to carefully craft products that turn positive user intentions–the desire to exercise, save money, or learn a language–into meaningful action.

items.title: Designing for Behavior Change
items.content:
Motivating users

Designing for behavior change involves motivating users to form new habits. Success in encouraging users to set money aside for retirement or increase daily physical activity can’t be measured in a single visit or a single interaction.

However, many success metrics on the web are focused on immediate victories: page visits, app downloads, conversion rates, lowered bounce rates. How can designers keep users motivated over the long term?

Extrinsic vs. intrinsic motivation

Designers can start by understanding that not all types of motivation is equally effective. Extrinsic motivation comes from external sources. Users might experience positive extrinsic motivation, such as feeling driven to complete a task to receive a reward, or negative extrinsic motivation, such as wanting to avoid punishment or shaming.

Users driven by extrinsic motivation (especially the negative kind) don’t tend to find the activity itself very satisfying, and their commitment is often short-lived and unlikely to survive a challenge.

Intrinsic motivation, on the other hand, is autonomous, personal, and internal. Users engage in an activity for its own sake, and the possibility of a reward is secondary to the enjoyment users inherently feel when performing the task.

The challenge with creating intrinsic motivation is that the designer can demonstrate how a product aligns with a user’s goals and values, but the source of motivation ultimately has to form within the user, not the designer.

“Creating something truly engaging and effective requires ceding control to the user.” – Amy Bucher, Ph.D., The Art of Designing for Behavior Change

Principles for changing user behavior

Understand user motivation

Providing a meaningful experience for users means understanding what brought them here in the first place. Before offering solutions, find out the following from the user:

  • Why do they want to change their behavior now rather than later?
  • What approaches have they tried before?
  • What approches have worked for them in the past?
  • What approches have failed them?

Noom, a weight management app, helps users identify what’s really important to them as part of the program onboarding. By leading users through a series of prompts and getting them to think about why their health really matters to them, Noom is able to simultaneously provide a customized experience and boost user motivation.

Completing a long onboarding experience can get tiring, so Noom periodically interrupts with social media testimonials from users. This is an example of social proof in design, where users reference the behavior of others to guide their own choices.

Offer meaningful choices

Offering meaningful choices doesn’t mean giving users lots of choices, as too many choices tend to be paralyzing. Techniques for reducing user choices include

  • Ask only important questions. Choices of lower consequence can be presented as modifiable defaults.
  • Offer good choices. Use your subject matter expertise to identify the best possible options for the user to choose from.
  • Personalize the experience. More advanced or knowledgeable users might review advanced features or specifications, but beginners need just enough detail to make an informed decision.
  • Make trade-offs explicit. Help users understand not only the benefits but also the consequences of their actions.

Use positive nudges

The Special Olympics USA Games 2022 mobile app uses prewritten, default messages to send positive cheers such as “Give it your all,” “Good luck,” and “High-5” with a minimum of effort.

The above is an example of a nudge, or a minor design feature that influences decision making. When taxi and ride-sharing apps suggest larger-than-average tips by default, this nudge leads to more generous user tipping.

Reward long-term commitments

Users who have let a positive habit lapse or have fallen short of a goal don’t like to hear about it, so Duolingo keeps the emphasis on positive accomplishments.

After being reminded of a 365-day streak of positive achievements, few users will break the streak casually.

Duolingo additionally users offers a Streak Freeze allowing users to pause a streak for a day when life gets in the way. Research suggests a bit of leeway is more motivating than an inflexible set of rules.

items.title: 🎬 Behavioral Design | What is Behavioral Design?
items.content:
Transcript

Hello, my name is Anwar and I'm part of the Product Design curriculum team here at Flatiron School. In this series of lectures we'll be discussing behavioral design.

Let's get started by defining behavioral design.

Behavioral design is an ethical framework for understanding and systematically influencing human behaviors in physical and digital environments. In the words of journalists and content strategist Jory MacKay, behavioral design focuses on change, not coercion. It emphasizes helping users achieve their own goals while using your product.

We've discussed previously that using techniques like Nir Eyal's Hook Model and addictive patterns such as infinite scroll to create unwanted habits in users is ethically problematic. But what if users want to change their behavior?

Here's a prompt for discussion. What apps have you used to try to break an old habit or build a new one? What was the experience like?

Let's look at some examples of behavioral design. One common category of behavioral design products is language acquisition apps. Duolingo encourages users to build daily language learning habits through a combination of positive encouragement and celebrating streaks of daily engagement.

Users might also use an application to help them form money saving habits and meet financial goals. Mint allows users to create a custom budgeting goal, then offers guidance on how to distribute paychecks, budget, and reduce spending to achieve that goal.

Many behavioral design products focus on improving user health and wellbeing. Fitbit supports a user's health journey using a system of notifications aimed at increasing physical activity, improving daily nutrition intake, and building better sleep habits.

items.title: 🎬 Behavioral Design | Understanding Decision Making
items.content:
Transcript

What do people think about when making a decision? Let's take a look.

To design for behavior change, we need to first consider how users make decisions.

In his textbook Designing For Behavior Change: Applying Psychology and Behavioral Economics, author Stephen Wendel says that when we understand the obstacles people face, we can help them take action.

Wendel introduces the CREATE framework to describe the mental process of making a decision. He describes each step in the framework – cue, reaction, evaluation, ability, timing, and experience – as tests the human brain uses to determine whether an action is worth pursuing.

Consider a choice many of us face daily, whether to use the elevator or stairs. What would the CREATE framework say about making this decision?

A cue is something that captures our attention. We're constantly accomplishing tasks without cues. These are tasks we pay no conscious attention to. Think about chatting with a coworker and unthinkingly following them onto an elevator. Sometimes external cues trigger our decision-making process. A sign indicating one of the building's two elevators is out of service might make us wonder whether waiting for the other elevator is worth it. Internal cues happen within the user's mind. Perhaps we remembered reading an article the other day indicating that taking the stairs, boosts our heart health.

Our brains are built to do most problem solving using System One thinking, which is fast and automatic. If we're used to taking the elevator every day, we might board the elevator as an unconscious reaction.

If we haven't boarded the elevator unconsciously, our brains can use System Two thinking to evaluate the costs and benefits of using the stairs. System Two thinking is slower and involves conscious effort. When evaluating our decision, we might focus on highlighting the benefits of the stairs, as the activity provides exercise. Or we might minimize the costs, reminding ourselves that taking the stairs is only a few minutes slower than the elevator. We might also downplay the alternatives. If the elevator is crowded and slow at lunchtime, this can make the stairs seem more appealing.

The fourth step in the CREATE decision-making framework is assessing whether we have the ability – in other words, the knowledge, skills, resources, and belief in success – to complete the action right now. If we're injured, we might need a resource to help us climb the stairs, such as a cane, a crutch, or a friend to carry our backpack. Or if we haven't been active lately, we might not believe ourselves capable of climbing multiple flights of stairs until we've mastered a smaller challenge.

Occasionally the timing of a decision comes with a pressing external urgency. The decision of whether to do our taxes now or later comes with an April 15th deadline and penalties if we're late. However, most other actions can be put off until tomorrow. Even if we'd like to exercise more by taking the stairs, we might decide not to start today.

Our past experience with an action has a powerful impact on whether we'll have the confidence to try it again. If someone made fun of you for climbing the stairs too slowly, or if you've slipped on the stairs and gotten hurt, these negative experiences might make you reluctant to try it again.

It's time for a workshop activity. A friend sent you an invite to Duolingo, and you've always wanted to learn a new language. Use the CREATE framework to analyze your decision making process on whether you download the app and get started today or not.

items.title: 🎬 Behavioral Design | Influencing User Decisions
items.content:
Transcript

Now that we understand the process users go through when making decisions, let's investigate how we can influence their choices.

Let's start this section with a reminder that behavioral design begins with the user. If the user doesn't want to change their behavior, we shouldn't manipulate them into changing or developing new habits against their will. If the user does want to change their behavior, however, the CREATE framework demonstrates that a lot can dissuade them from actually taking action. How can we remove obstacles that might prevent a user from making better decisions?

To design for behavior change, it's not enough to understand how the mind makes decisions. We need a process that helps us intervene when users are struggling to make the right decision. The DECIDE process is an acronym for a 6-step process that helps us decide what sort of intervention is appropriate for a specific user facing a specific situation. First we define the problem. Then we explore the context in which the problem occurs. Next we craft an intervention, implement the intervention within the product, and determine the impact. Finally, we evaluate the results and determine next steps.

Returning to our example of a user who wishes to become more active by taking more steps per day, how might a fitness apps such as Fitbit use the DECIDE process to influence decision-making? Can a digital product help encourage users to choose the stairs instead of the elevator?

When defining the problem, we start by identifying the audience and understanding what they want to achieve. People who want to get more active or take more steps per day are a rather broad audience. We might narrow that down to urban office workers who want more activity during their workday, since these are workers who often face the choice of using an elevator or the stairs. We should also define what success looks like. Is an average increase of three flights of stairs per day achievable? How long should it take for users to form this new habit?

What stands in the way of users achieving their goals? While exploring the context, we gather data about the obstacles preventing users from changing their behavior. We can learn about user attitudes by surveying and interviewing them, and use contextual inquiry to observe their behavior. If we're a fitness application trying to encourage more physical activity during the workday,

we might also want to gather information about the relationship between office workers and their phones and smart watches.

As you gather data, you'll start to form groups of users based on their previous experiences. Some users will have tried fitness apps before and some won't. Some users will have negative associations with climbing stairs and some won't. These groupings are important because it's unlikely one solution will satisfy every type of persona.

When crafting an intervention, choose a persona from your context-gathering stage, and come up with a hypothesis for intervening in that user's decision-making process. Then prototype an interface you can use to test that hypothesis.

When thinking of how to encourage users to take the stairs, our first instinct might be to cue the user with a well-timed push notification. However behavioral design tactics to motivate users should consider all six stages of the CREATE framework. Let's look at timing, for example. How can we motivate users to take the stairs now, rather than putting it off until later? One possibility might be notifying the user they're closing in on a goal. A user who realizes they're nearing 7,900 steps for the day might take the stairs to reach 8,000. What about ability and experience? How can we convince users who have struggled to build exercise habits that they're capable this time? "Fresh start" messaging can help – that is, messaging that makes this journey feel special and past attempts feel irrelevant. In addition, some products use social proof: the idea that if your friends can meet behavior change goals, so can you.

Once you've settled on an intervention, it's time to prototype and test. In addition to testing the effectiveness of the intervention, you'll want to assess the ethics of the solution. An ethical product is transparent about its purpose, doesn't harm users or cause them to grow addicted, and ensures all user actions are voluntary. That last reminder is a critical one. Behavioral design is ethical only when users want to change their behavior and can make informed decisions to do so.

To test the impact of your intervention, make sure you're only conducting one experiment at a time. Then run an A/B test. Divide users at random into a control group, who see the old version of your product, versus a test group who experiences the new prototype. As with any test, make sure you've clearly defined what you're hoping to learn. You'll want a clear hypothesis stating the outcome your team is expecting to happen as well as metrics for defining success.

Like any design process, the DECIDE process is an iterative one. If your intervention was successful, you might implement it as is, or continue to refine it to maximize its impact. On the other hand, many behavioral design interventions aren't successful. Making beneficial decisions is hard for users, and nudging users towards positive habits is hard for product designers. Be prepared to back up to previous stages in the DECIDE process frequently and run numerous experiments before settling on the right approach.

items.title: 🎬 Behavioral Design | Designing For Decision Making
items.content:
Transcript

What kinds of design principles make decision-making easier for users?

While providing users with lots of options sounds great in theory, more choices isn't always better. In the year 2000, an upscale California food market increased its sales of gourmet jam by 27% by simply reducing the number of available flavors from 24 to 6. Too many choices overwhelm people, a phenomenon sometimes called analysis paralysis. As an example, think of the last time you struggled to find anything to watch on Netflix, despite having thousands of movies and shows to choose from.

Curated options especially help when people make decisions with health or financial consequences that can be stressful for users. Roobrik, a web app helping users consider assisted living options for loved ones needing care, helps limit analysis paralysis by only providing a few good options. After gathering information from the user about the loved one's needs and health, the app provides a few recommended options along with a clear rationale for why those choices might be appropriate.

While your product might provide the option of an expert level experience for advanced users, everyday users don't want to be faced with a ton of detail when making decisions. Present high level categories and the most critical details first, then allow users to explore additional details on a separate screen or by uncollapsing a panel. The Weight Watchers app pictured here frees users from counting calories by bundling nutritional information into one metric, a daily point system. When entering meals, users are initially faced with only a few simple, instantly recognizable categories: veggies, water, breakfast, lunch, dinner.

People don't always understand the consequences of a decision. By making the potential downside to a decision transparent, you'll inspire trust in your product and help users make more confident choices. While the Mint budgeting app recommends a method of debt reduction called the debt snowball, the approach is ineffective for users with high-interest debt. If the app didn't make this drawback obvious, users could easily select the wrong strategy.

Understanding user tendencies and biases can help designers nudge users towards a positive decision. For example, the anchoring bias means that people often estimate value by focusing on a single, initial piece of information. Designers can take advantage of this bias by implementing well-chosen default values. In 2015, the British nonprofit organization Oxfam saw a 23% increase in donations simply by adding a £4 suggested default before its Donate Now call to action. This change reduces the decision burden on users. Instead of worrying what a reasonable donation might look like, they can accept or adjust the recommended value.

The sunk cost fallacy means that people often continue investing in an activity because of past time, effort, or money sunk into the activity, even when the reward is no longer available. This is the tendency that keeps us waiting for a bus that's 20 minutes late rather than searching for alternate transportation. When apps such as Duolingo reward user streaks, in addition to providing a positive feeling, it reminds the user they don't want to waste their accumulated time investment.

Now it's time for discussion. Developing new, positive habits is a lengthy process for users. Knowing this, what challenges do you think behavioral designers face when testing and measuring the success of their designs?

items.title: Information Design
items.content:
What is information design?

Information design is the practice of presenting information in a way that reduces uncertainty and makes it accessible and easily understood by most users.

People consume information constantly–including instructions, figures, data, and tables. Designers must work with a set of defined objectives to ensure the right message is transmitted clearly and accurately. Complex data must be organized and simplified in a way that enhances comprehension.

In many ways, information design overlaps with information architecture, in that you are designing information spaces for optimal use and understanding.

In the diagram above, based on ideas by Jessie James Garrett in The Elements of User Experience, you see that information design begins with a deep understanding of the data and content, which determines the functionality, that in turn, makes up the bulk of the presentation layer.

What is data visualization?

Information visualization, or data visualization, it the process by which data is represented visually so that the recipient builds an accurate representation of it in their mind.

In its raw form, data is mostly worthless; not adequate for finding meaning or communicating. To have value, it must be organized, transformed, and presented in a way that gives it meaning.

Unstructured vs structured data

Unstructured data has no model and is typically qualitative and categorical in nature. It's not easily searchable and includes a range of formats like text, audio, social media posts, email, imagery, and sensor data.

In contrast, structured data is highly organized and searchable. Structured data is typically stored in a relational database where it can be sorted, ordered, filtered, combined, grouped, categorized, measured, and counted.

You are likely familiar with many tools that use a relational database. Airtable, Notion, and Asana are software tools that let users manipulate data stored in a relational database. Records (objects) are stored in rows, while attributes are stored in columns.

Visualizing information

Data visualization is also used to present information in a graphical format. Once the problem and data to be represented is defined, product designers can select the right dimensions, structures, and interactions necessary for the visualization.

items.title: Design For Scanning, Not Reading
items.content:
How users read on the web

A frequently-referenced 1997 study by the Nielsen Norman Group offers a flippantly accurate two-word response to the question of how users read on the web: they don’t.

The idea isn’t that users never read, or that users avoid information that requires reading. Instead, users simply don’t want to waste time reading a web page that doesn’t apply to them.

F-patterns

A 2006 Nielsen Norman study used eye-tracking–a method of observing users via sensors that measure eye position and eye movement–to uncover a scanning pattern called the F-pattern. When faced with unfamiliar content, users sweep their eyes over the top and left sides of the page in a pattern that roughly suggests the letter F, looking for relevant words and phrases. If they don’t find any, they tend to abandon the page pretty quickly.

To this day, some web content is still formatted to support this user tendency. For example, Google’s search results tend to place most content on the top and left side of the page.

However, formatting content based on the F-pattern is not realistic for many sites and apps. A more effective approach is to understand the user tendency to scan before deciding to read, and to format content accordingly.

Designing to support scanning

Make no mistake, the F-shaped scanning pattern is bad for users and business: it means that users may skip important content simply because it appears on the right side of the page. – Kara Pernice, Nielsen Norman Group

If the F-pattern sounds like a bleak depiction of user behavior, it’s important to emphasize that users only use this method to scan badly formatted content. If body copy appears as a “wall of text”, with no cues provided to emphasize important information, users employ F-pattern scanning to minimize their own effort in interpreting the page content.

In his web usability textbook Don’t Make Me Think, author Steve Krug identifies four principles that support scanning and reduce user effort in identifying useful information.

Use plenty of headings.

Well-written headings and subheadings allow users to quickly decide which parts of the page to read, scan, or skip.

Think about Wikipedia mobile: subheadings initially appear collapsed, and users can decide to uncollapse and read each one, or not, depending on the relevance to the user.

Nielsen Norman Group calls a scanning pattern fixated mostly on headings and subheadings, with deliberate, occasional glances at the body copy in between, a layer-cake pattern, and notes that this pattern leads to a much more successful information design experience.

Supporting scanning this way only works provided you follow two important design rules:

  • Make sure there is an obvious visual distinction between heading levels. More important headings should be given more visual weight than less important subheadings.
  • Make sure your headings don’t float between paragraphs. It should be immediately obvious what content the heading belongs to.

Keep paragraphs short.

Seriously, short paragraphs are fine.

The longer the paragraph, the harder it is for readers to keep their place, and the harder it is for users to scan the paragraph for key information.

Just don’t forget to provide ample space between paragraphs. Otherwise they’ll read as one continuous block of text.

Use bulleted lists.

Don’t bury key takeaways in the middle of a sentence. Bulleted lists are much easier to scan.

Emphasize key terms.

Using bold text to highlight key terms makes them easier to find, provided you apply this technique sparingly.

items.title: Lists
items.content:
Preparing a list

Lists are used practically everywhere in software: movies, articles, bank statements, songs, emails, files, and on and on. The first question you must answer is: why does someone need this list? You should have research that indicates the need for displaying information and what people will want to do with it.

  1. Why does someone need this list?
    • Are they browsing to buy items?
    • Do they need an overview or the ability to deep dive into one item by clicking for more information?
    • How much control do users need over the presentation of the list?
    • Will they want to re-arrange or edit items in the list?
    • Will they want to compare items?
    • How much information should be displayed in the list view?
  2. What are the non-visual characteristics of the list?
    • What is the length of the list?
    • What order should the list default to: alphabetical, date, time?
    • Will it require a grouping scheme?
    • Are there categories the user will understand?
    • What are the items like?
    • Do they require images or dynamic content?
    • What interactions are necessary for users to perform critical functions?

The answers to questions like these will determine most of the design decisions you need to make, so make sure your answers are informed by user research and not guesses.

Common list patterns

Split View

This is a common pattern for displaying information; most email clients offer options for split-view. Users can quickly see the overall structure of the list on one side, and then view an object’s details on the other. This pattern reduces effort because it's easy to scan, interact with, and doesn’t ask the user to change context.

Overcast offers a split, or two-panel view, that allows users to browse podcast episodes on the left, and read deeper information and interact with the podcast controls on the right.

Since Overcast is primarily used on mobile devices, the designers opted to stack the displayed attributes (title, date, length, description) vertically rather than horizontally.

Tips

  • Make the selected item visually obvious.
  • Give users the ability to navigate the items via keyboard arrows.

Reeder uses two list views to navigate two levels of hierarchy, the tags list and the article list, with the selected article in the right hand panel. As you resize the screen, Reeder changes to a drilldown view that is more appropriate for smaller views.

Users might struggle with this pattern on smaller mobile devices. The physical display must be large enough to view two panels simultaneously. Apple News handles this by using a two-panel layout on iPad and Desktop, but then switches to a one-window drilldown on iPhone.

Drilldown

Just like the mobile view in Apple News, a one-window drilldown replaces the list view with the details or contents of the selected item. This pattern has the advantage of being able to quickly jump in and out of items by using a shallow hierarchy.

Make sure the user can intuitively navigate back to the list view. If appropriate, include the ability to move to the previous or next item in the list view without having to go back to the main list.

Inlay

A third option is to display item information in the context of the list itself via expanding and closing rows. This allows the user to stay in the list view and but also browse and compare items quickly.

Readwise uses an inlay to allow users access to functionality to edit the selected item. Since you can expand as many rows as you want, Readwise includes a global expand/collapse control in the list bar to allow users to quickly reset to a collapsed state.

Tips

  • When an item is expanded, the other list items are pushed downward.
  • Use similar gestures for expand and collapse.
  • Keep controls near the top of the list item so users do not have to move the mouse to collapse it.

items.title: Tables
items.content:
Data tables

Data tables show sets of data across rows and columns in a grid-like format. It's an easy to way to organize information, and it supports comparative analysis on categorical objects. Data tables often have interactive components and tools to query or manipulate the data.

Tips

  • Header row with attribute titles. Clicking a title sorts the rows by that attribute. Notice the dash (–) in the header checkbox indicates an intermediate state since some rows are selected and some are not.
  • Selected rows with check boxes. The background highlight is another selected-state indicator.
  • Control row. The ability to delete only appears when a row is selected.
  • Search field.
  • Contextual menu allows for editing individual rows.
  • Pagination control bar.

Typography for tables

  • Left-align text.
  • Right-align numbers to help users make comparisons when scanning down columns.
    • Use consistent precision, the same number of decimal places.
    • If numbers don't use the same decimal places or format, align to the decimal place to aid in scanning.
  • Match heading alignment with the data below.
  • Use a monospace font or, even better, tabular numerals designed so every digit takes up the same amount of space.

Styling tables

Fit columns to support the size of the data. Columns don’t all need equal space.

Apply Gestalt principles of proximity and similarity:

  • Try using alignment, spacing, and grouping to organize the data instead of additional visual elements like borders (called "rules") or zebra stripes.
  • Tables should not look like nets, or an excel sheet. If you use borders, they should be light in order to create a distinction, not a barricade.

Design Patterns for Data Tables

The following examples were created by product designer Andrew Coyle.

Fixed Header

Fixing the row header as a user scrolls provides context on what column the user is on.

Horizontal Scroll

Horizontal scrolling is inevitable when presenting large datasets. It is good practice to place identifier data in the first column.

As an advanced feature, enable individual locking of columns so users can compare data with multiple anchoring identifiers.

Resizable Columns

Resizing columns allows users to see abbreviated data in full.

Row Style, Zebra Stripes, Line Divisions, Free Form

The row style helps users scan data. Reducing visual noise by removing row lines or zebra stripes works well for small datasets. Users may lose their place when parsing larger datasets. Line divisions help users keep their place.

Alternating rows (aka zebra stripes) help users keep their place when scanning long horizontal datasets. Although they cause usability problems when there is a small number of rows because users may ascribe meaning to the highlighted rows.

Display Density

Smaller row height enables the user to view more data without the need for scrolling. However, it affects scannability leading to parsing errors. That is why many successful data table designs incorporate the ability to control display density.

Visual Table Summary

A visual data summary provides an overview of the accompanying table. It allows the user to spot patterns and issues in aggregate before actioning summary insights.

Pagination

Pagination works by presenting a set number of rows in a view, with the ability to navigate to another set. The above example provides the ability to customize the row count per view.

Infinite scroll often replaces this pattern. Infinite scroll progressively loads results as a user scrolls. Infinite scroll works well for discovery websites but is usually disastrous for prioritization apps.

Hover Actions

Presenting additional action when a user hovers reduces visual clutter. However, it can cause discoverability issues because the user needs to interact with the table to expose the presentation of actions.

Also, don’t forget that touchscreen devices lack hover states.

Inline Editing

Inline editing allows the user to change data without navigating to a separate details view.

Expandable Rows

Expandable rows allow the user to evaluate additional information without losing their context.

Quick View

Much like expandable rows, quick view enables a user to view additional information while staying in context.

Modal

Modals allow the user to stay within the table view but provides more focus on the additional information and actions.

Row to Details

Clicking on a row link transforms the table into a view with list items on the left and additional details on the right. It enables a user to parse large datasets, as well as reference many items without losing their place.

Sortable Columns

Column sorting allows users to organize rows alphabetically and numerically.

Basic Filtering

Basic filtering allows users to manipulate the data presented in the table.

Filter Columns

This design pattern allows users to assign filtering parameters to specific columns.

Searchable Columns

This design pattern allows a user to search specific values within each column.

Add Columns

This pattern allows users to add columns from a dataset. It is a way to keep the table’s data limited to essential information and enables the user to add additional columns based on their use case.

Customizable Columns

The customizable columns feature enables users to pick the columns they want to see and sort accordingly. The feature may include the ability to save presets for later use.

items.title: 🎬 Information Design | What is Information Design?
items.content:
Transcript

Hello, my name is Anwar and I'm part of the Product Design curriculum team here at Flatiron School. In this series of lectures we'll be discussing information design. So how do we define information design? To quote author and information designer Joel Katz, our job as information designers is to clarify, to simplify, and to make information accessible to the people who will need it and use it to make important decisions. Information needs to be in a form they can understand and use meaningfully, and to tell the truth of what things mean and how they work.

In other words, information design is concerned with making complex information easier to understand and use. It emerged as a response to people's need to understand and use technical information as well as computer interfaces.

Information design combines the unique disciplines of typography, graphic design, linguistics, psychology, ergonomics, and computing. When users are faced with a complex task, your job as a designer is to make it as clear and simple as possible. While this can be achieved in a variety of ways, it's critical above all to understand the user's mental model.

What factors shape the way users understand the information in front of them? You can also assist users by using plain, understandable language, by carefully labeling interface elements, and by reducing visual chaos by using grids On the screen in front of us, we see a Venn diagram visualizing the overlapping components of information design.

Successful information design is found at the intersection of data, visual graphics, and narrative storytelling.

items.title: 🎬 Information Design | Data vs. Information
items.content:
Transcript

Are data and information the same thing? And if not, what makes them different? Let's find out. In this example, we see a spreadsheet full of sales records. One table is labeled Sales and another is labeled Quota. Is this data meaningful to you? Or how about this example? This time we see assorted figures related to different United States counties for the year 2019.

What do you learn from scanning the figures? Are you able to interpret the data from reading it? If the last two slides didn't mean much of anything, you're not alone. Data without context, labels, or organization is meaningless. When designers add context and organization to data, they convert that data into information

that can be used and acted upon by the viewer. Converting data into information starts with grouping related data and providing meaningful labels so viewers can understand what they're seeing and quickly find what they're looking for. If your data is interactive, it helps to provide filters so viewers can isolate the data most meaningful to them.

You can also highlight trends or averages within the data, if that helps the viewer understand it faster. According to a 2009 report by the University of California, San Diego, the average American consumes 34 gigabytes of data each day.

If you're having trouble visualizing what 34 gigabytes looks like, well, that's exactly my point. Data only truly becomes valuable when it is structured and actionable. Cognitive overload happens all too easily on the web. The more we ask users to do the hard work of converting data into information, the harder it becomes for them to make a decision.

Calling attention to what's important within a set of information reduces fatigue and leads to better informed choices. On the screen, we see two dates in November 2020 that at a glance look pretty similar to each other. The column on the left features the dates alone. What do you learn from this column?

If you said, not much, I'm inclined to agree with you. In the column on the right, each data is supported by a bit of colorful text. What do you learn from this column? Here we see that whatever it was that was due on November 6th is now one day overdue, while whatever was due on November 10th isn't due for three more days. In this case, it was a pretty subtle change that turned unprocessed data into actionable information.

items.title: 🎬 Information Design | Information Design as a Task
items.content:
Transcript

What kinds of projects does an information designer work on, and how does an information designer know when to take action? The more complex the information being presented, the harder the information designer will need to work to simplify the presentation and allow the user to make meaningful, informed decisions.

What are some tasks information designers might take on? Online forms are notoriously difficult for users of all abilities to complete. Information designers help by breaking the form into discrete steps and minimizing, wherever possible, the number of fields users are required to fill out. Learning portals offer interactive online learning. Information

designers can help organize and present information appropriate to what the user is trying to learn and for the user's current level of understanding. When designing annual reports, it's important to understand what leadership is looking to learn from the reports and what readers want to know about the health or expansion of the business.

As for service blueprints, these are extensions of customer journey maps that align to a business goal, such as reducing redundancies or improving the employee experience. Finally, infographics are charts or diagrams used to reduce data complexity and share information visually. An information designer makes the complex simpler by removing unnecessary information.

This often means embracing a progressive disclosure approach. Progressive disclosure sequences information and tasks across multiple screens. Start by placing the information most vital to your user in front of them. Then allow them to dig deeper with a click or a tap. On screen, we have two examples of instructions for taking medicine.

What techniques have been used to improve user understanding in the version on the right? Why is this important?

Now it's time for discussion. Is there a link between information design and user experience? How does information design affect the customer experience?

items.title: 🎬 Information Design | Information Design as a Mindset
items.content:
Transcript

So how do we start thinking like information designers? The conversion of data into information provides just the foundation for this visual known as the DIKW or data, information, knowledge, and wisdom pyramid. We've done our job as information designers when users can convert that information into knowledge, meaning they can use it to make decisions. Even better, that knowledge can bring wisdom, or the ability to apply knowledge to real life situations and predict future outcomes.

Here we see a site map diagram for an informational website. Information architecture helps structure information and makes users more confident in the actions they take when locating information within a system. A customer journey map helps you design information with the user's mental model in mind.

Building around user pain points minimizes confusion and keeps users moving towards a goal. This user journey map shows how a person interacts with a brand or product over time and through different channels.

Note the influence of empathy mapping here. At each stage in the journey, we should be aware of what the user thinks and feels and what motivates each action. The more you practice information design, the better you'll get at applying its principles to every asset you create as a designer. Whether you're communicating with users, teammates, or stakeholders, and whether you're designing body text, a set of data from a spreadsheet, or a diagram indicating a journey from start to finish, you'll want to make sure everything you design provides information, knowledge, and wisdom to your audience.

items.title: 🎬 Information Design | Practicing Information Design
items.content:
Transcript

In what ways can you begin applying what you've learned to your information design practice? As we answer that question, let's look at a quote from statistician and information designer Edward Tufte, who reminds us that confusion is a failure of design, not an attribute of information. If audiences can't understand our information design, the issue isn't some quality inherent to the data, but rather a storytelling issue. 

We need to identify what our audience needs from the data and make our most important content legible, meaningful, and usable. 

You can practice information design by omitting unnecessary words from your writing and by using plain, conversational language. 

You can practice information design by formatting your content to support visual scanning. 

You can practice information design by seeking opportunities to tell stories with data. And to turn that data into information viewers can use as a basis for decision-making. 

And here's a practice opportunity. Review your past assignments and deliverables to find opportunities for converting data into meaningful information. Organize your content. Provide meaningful labels. Apply visual design techniques to reduce clutter, increase white space, and draw attention to the most important information. 

And make sure your information tells a meaningful story.

items.title: Privacy by Design
items.content:
Designing for security and safety

The amount of data and personal information being exchanged over the internet today is massive. With that in mind, companies need to be more careful than ever about how they handle that data to protect themselves and their customers.

As designers, the need for security and safety for our users and clients needs to be at the forefront of our designs. By being proactive in how we design our products with security in mind, we can minimize the scope of damage done if catastrophe were to strike such as hacks and data breaches.

One primary challenge for designers is to determine the most appropriate amount of information needed from users to begin with. What information do you need from your user in order to create an experience for the user that feels personal to them, yet adequately protects them in the case of an emergency? One popular framework leveraged by professionals today is the Privacy by Design model.

Privacy by Design is a methodology we can apply to our designs to ensure that the privacy of individuals is protected by our product. The purpose of this framework is to help designers think ahead to anticipate, manage and potentially prevent any data or privacy issues before we release our product for the end-users consumption.

As products are assessed for other aspects of design such as desirability, usability, and viability, designers should also evaluate their products with these 8 principles in mind to determine how effectively they are managing the data and privacy of their users.

Proactive, not reactive.

Take a high level look at your product and your company's practices. Be mindful of what data you are asking from users and why. What privacy issues can you anticipate and what are the risks associated with them? Knowing the facts ahead of time can help the team better weigh what type of information should be collected and why it is important.

Privacy is the default setting.

As you design your product or service, it is best practice to protect personal data automatically versus sharing it with other users or third parties. When privacy is the default setting, the user will not need to take additional steps to protect their data. This also goes a long way in building user confidence and trust.

Embed privacy into the design.

Ensure your users that their data is protected when filling in forms and other types of inputs. Consider how transparent your messaging is and give the users the ability to protect their data if they so choose.

Avoid trade-offs

In some situations it may feel as though you can only provide one of the two, security or privacy. Reevaluate your objectives and consider why information is needed and how mission critical it is that your user’s provide that information.

End-to-end security

When evaluating the data you are collecting from users, consider the entire lifecycle it will go through. Once you have collected and processed data sets, how will it be destroyed securely when it is no longer needed? Also consider how that can be communicated clearly and succinctly to your users.

Keep it open

As you get closer to launching your products, you may use a third party product or service to help collect data. Be open and transparent to your users about this and ensure that those third parties are able to be verified if your users want to dig further. It is also best practice to be entirely transparent about what data you are collecting and the purpose of collecting it.

Keep it user centered

The interest of individual users is the top priority for designers when building products. Consider the needs of your users and provide them with controls over their own data usage. They should also be given clear and appropriate notice when any of their privacy settings are changed for any reason.

Don’t sacrifice privacy for personalization

More and more products are taking curated approaches to better serve their individual users. However, personalization can come at the expense of privacy as more and more data is collected from users. When evaluating your product for the aforementioned criteria or making design decisions for the product, always opt for user privacy over personalization.

items.title: Data Privacy in the News
items.content:
What laws affect data privacy?

In Europe

As of the time of this writing, the strictest data privacy laws are found in the European Union, thanks to the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). The regulation went into effect in 2018, and impacts companies and organizations everywhere, as long as they target or collect data related to people in the European Union. Some of the principles outlined by the GDPR include

  • Organizations must be transparent about the data collected, and use it only for the purpose specified to the user
  • Organizations should only collect as much data as is absolutely necessary for the purpose specified to the user
  • Organizations may only store data for as long as it’s needed
  • Organizations must protect data using appropriate security, integrity, and confidentiality

A number of other nations have adopted similar laws, and California modeled its 2018 California Consumer Privacy Act after the GDPR.

In America

Except for California, America’s laws regarding data privacy are considerably less strict than the European Union, although Illinois allows users to sue companies over mishandling of biometric data used to measure user physical and behavioral characteristics, such as facial recognition software.

However, a number of companies have been subject to class-action lawsuits for misusing personal user data.

“The tide is turning,” according to Hagens Berman Sobol Shapiro partner Thomas E. Loeser. “Big Tech has gotten away with a lot over the last 15 to 20 years because regulation has been lax,” he added. As technology companies have been ahead of regulators and consumers in terms of understanding the system, Big Tech has been able to “take advantage of users” when it comes to the privacy of personal data as well as antitrust issues, he said.

Christine Schiffner, 'The Tide Is Turning' on Big Tech as Plaintiffs Firms File More Data Privacy Lawsuits

Notable lawsuits

As users continue to take action against tech companies for misusing their personal data, the information here will change. Here is a list of a few noteworthy class-action lawsuits as of the time of this writing.

Facebook

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg’s cavalier attitude towards user privacy has earned him his own dark pattern. Privacy Zuckering means tricking a user into publicly sharing unintended personal information.

The term dates back to 2009, when Facebook announced it would treat friend lists as publicly available information. Users wanting to keep their friend list private had to discover it in an unlikely area of the User Profile page, rather than as part of their Privacy Settings.

Users attempting to disable an additionally unwelcome feature called Instant Personalization, which allowed advertisers to collect and log user profile information, were confronted with this intimidating modal window:

“Sharing your (Facebook) data requires radically less work than protecting it” – Tim Jones, Electronic Frontier Foundation

In recent years, Facebook has continued to make headlines for its poor data privacy practices.

  • In 2019, the Federal Trade Commission announced a record $5 billion dollar fine against Facebook that imposed six new privacy requirements, including
    • A ban on taking user phone numbers for security purposes and then sharing them with advertisers
    • Requiring affirmative consent from users before using facial recognition
  • In 2020, Facebook was ordered to pay $650 million in a class-action lawsuit regarding Facebook’s practice of collecting and storing digital scans of user faces without prior notice or consent.
  • In 2021, Facebook paid an additional $90 million for using cookies to track internet activity of users browsing other websites containing Facebook “Like” buttons.

Zoom

In 2021, Zoom settled an $85 million dollar lawsuit due to the company’s policy of sharing user personal data with Facebook, Google, and LinkedIn.

In addition, poor security within the Zoom application led to the 2020 rise of “Zoombombing”, in which internet trolls interrupt video chats to post pornographic materials or hateful language and threats.

Google

In 2020 through 2022, Google has been hit by class action lawsuits in response to several of its data privacy practices:

  • A 2018 investigation by the Associated Press discovered that many Google applications on both iOS and Android store location data even when users select a privacy setting meant to prevent Google from doing so.
  • Another lawsuit accuses Google of collecting information from users even when using Incognito Mode, a feature of the Chrome browser intended to provide a “private” experience.

TikTok

In February 2021, TikTok agreed to a $92 million settlement for its practice of analyzing facial features in user videos to determine the user’s age, race/ethnicity, and gender without the user’s consent. TikTok used the gathered facial recognition data to recommend content and profiles for the user to follow.

Better practices

While the consistent mishandling of personal data by companies like Facebook can cause frustration or despair among users, some larger tech companies have demonstrated a commitment to protecting user privacy.

Mozilla Firefox

In a web page promoting Firefox Browser, Mozilla claims that “Firefox protects your privacy in every product”, and that Firefox blocks more than 2,000 online trackers (in which companies use scripts such as cookies to collect, store, and share information about user browsing activity) automatically.

Mozilla’s Data Privacy Principles include

  • No surprises: using and sharing information in a way that is transparent and benefits the user.
  • User control: keep users in control of their data and online experiences.
  • Limited data: collect only needed data, and delete when no longer necessary.
  • Sensible settings: design for a thoughtful balance of safety and user experience.
  • Defense in depth: maintain multi-layered security controls and practices.

Apple

While Apple has faced criticism in other areas of product development, such as its poor labor practices, since 2015 Apple has been steadily adding privacy improvements to iOS and the Safari browser.

As of iOS 14.5, developers need to request and receive the user’s permission in order to track their online activity. In addition, Apple added an App Privacy section to each listing in the App Store detailing the types of data an app might be collecting.

items.title: 🎬 Information Design Ethics | Information as a Right
items.content:
Transcript

 Hello, my name is Anwar and I'm part of the Product Design curriculum team here at Flatiron School. In this series of lectures, we'll be discussing information design ethics. Let's start with protecting the user's right to access information. In the words of author, instructor, and communication designer, Jorge Frascara, access to information should be regarded as a human right. 

Information design should not be seen as an option, but a necessity. 

You could use this slide as a checklist to measure the respectfulness of your information design. Information design respects people when it focuses on user needs, when it's ethical and practical, when it's been made accessible for all types of users, when it's been designed attractively, and when it's relevant to the user's area of interest. 

The information we provide should be readable, understandable, complete, accurate, timely, and usable. We should consider how people interact with our designs and double check that we didn't confuse, harm, or mislead the user, but that we instead provided straightforward information that could be used to inform decision-making. 

The pyramid on screen demonstrates that while delighting the user is important, it's only the capstone of a respectful experience. The foundation of the respectful design pyramid is human rights and it depends on protecting user privacy and security, being open and honest, meeting accessibility requirements, and designing products that are environmentally sustainable. 

Above the foundation of the pyramid we see a level labeled human effort, which speaks to minimizing the effort users need to access our information. The products and services we design should be functional, convenient, and reliable.

items.title: 🎬 Information Design Ethics | PAPA
items.content:
Transcript

In this section of our lecture on information design ethics, we'll be discussing an ethical framework called PAPA. In 1986, an author and ethics professor named Richard Mason proposed the PAPA framework to address four ethical issues society would likely face in the information age: privacy, accuracy, property, and accessibility. 

The Papa framework asks questions every responsible information designer needs to be able to answer, such as what things can people keep to themselves and not be forced to reveal to others? Who is responsible for the authenticity, fidelity and accuracy of information? 

Who owns information as well as the channels through which information is transmitted? And what information does a person or an organization have the right to obtain? 

The 2018 General Data Protection Regulation or GDPR protects the personal data of European Union citizens, including their name, address, location, health information, and cultural profile. Organizations are required to be transparent about data collected, to collect only as much data as is necessary, 

and to store it for only as long as it's needed. Businesses must also protect the security of user data, and make their data collection policies transparent to the user. California passed a similar law later the same year. 

Here's a question for discussion. Doctors and lawyers both commit to upholding a code of ethics, and a serious enough violation can result in a loss of the license to practice medicine or law. Do you think designers should be held to a similar standard? 

In 2017, Mike Monteiro, the co-founder and design director of Mule Design, published an influential essay called A Designer's Code of Ethics in which he states when we knowingly produce work that is intended to harm, we are abdicating our responsibility. When we ignorantly produce work that harms others because we didn't consider the full ramifications of that work, we are doubly guilty. 

Studies show that graphic warning labels on cigarette packs increase the likelihood of quitting tobacco, as the warnings provide behavioral nudges to remind smokers about the health risks associated with smoking. Attempting to increase profits for your stakeholder does not mean designers can overlook user safety. 

Creating ethical designs means presenting a complete set of information upfront and letting users make their own judgment based on that information. 

Think about how much data your devices collect about your habits. Did your apps provide a warning as to how your data would be used? Did you consent to having your data collected? Are you confident your data will be kept private and secure? Do you believe any of your data could be used unethically against you? 

In 2018, Uber paid a $148 million settlement due to its poor data privacy practices. Uber employees were allowed unlimited access to customer data, and hackers were able to steal the personal information of 25 million customers and drivers. In addition, Uber used an internal software program called Greyball to hide driver location and ride sharing information from government officials trying to enforce local taxi laws. 

Now it's time for another discussion question. As a designer, how can you follow your own moral and ethical codes that might not always align with the practices of the company you work for?

items.title: 🎬 Information Design Ethics | Consumption of Information
items.content:
Transcript

Let's talk about how today's users consume information. We'll start with two quotes from very different sources. The first is from political scientist Herbert A. Simon, who says what information consumes is rather obvious. It consumes the attention of its recipients. The second is from singer Tom Waits, who says we are buried beneath the weight of information, which is being confused with knowledge; 

quantity is being confused with abundance and wealth with happiness. 

According to a 2012 book by Clay A. Johnson called The Information Diet, users spend 11 out of every 24 hours consuming information. This includes traditional media sources such as television, newspapers, and magazines, but also websites, social media feeds, and text and instant messaging. To quote the author, "just as too much junk food can lead to obesity, too much junk information can lead to cluelessness". 

But what can users do to filter out empty, meaningless data and find nutritious, useful information? 

What motivates the way people consume information? Sometimes we seek information to help us solve a problem or make a decision. Information consumption has a social aspect as well, as we want to appear knowledgeable and share information that supports our point of view with our peers. And of course, curiosity plays a role as well. 

We might desire knowledge for the sake of knowledge, but we might also be tempted to respond to clickbait, a term describing a sensationalized headline or article snippet designed to draw attention. Or sometimes we're acting unconsciously to trigger the dopamine release that accompanies refreshing a newsfeed or performing an action inspired by a notification on our phones. 

Filter bubbles can make your views feel more universally accepted and less disputed than they are in reality. For example, a video sharing app may suggest videos that align favorably with your political viewpoint. Your social media network of friends who share your beliefs can similarly create an artificial echo chamber of data that confirms your existing point of view. 

It takes work for users to verify the correctness of online information and identify sources that are reliable, reputable, and trustworthy. Consuming misinformation can give users a distorted worldview and lead to flawed decision-making. 

In his book The Information Diet, author Clay A. Johnson argues that while overwhelming the user with information leads to shortened attention spans and shallower social relationships, "information overload" is the wrong term because it blames the information. Johnson prefers the term "overconsumption", which means users need to manage how they consume information daily. 

What do you think? How much control do users have over information consumption? 

Onscreen we see a 2018 screenshot of the unsubscribe process from Daily Yahoo. The wording is lengthy, and the call to action actually cancels the unsubscription process. Which brings up some followup questions. Do users always understand the data consumption options in front of them? Can designers help reduce information overconsumption? What responsibility do designers have in making sure users can make informed choices? 

So here's an interesting opportunity to do some deeper thinking around information design ethics. LinkedIn is a vital platform for making industry connections and job searching. But does it present data ethically and protect user data? Using the Poppa framework–that's privacy, accuracy, property, and access–spend some time analyzing how LinkedIn presents information to its users, and how user rights are protected.
