items.title: Data Visualization Basics
items.content:
What is Data Visualization?

Data visualization is necessary because raw data, in the form of unorganized facts and numbers, is difficult to use for most people.

For example, if you read the United States national debt in April 2022 was $30 trillion dollars, that’s certainly a large number, and a lot of money. But it’s impossible for the average person to visualize what such a large number looks like. And without any context, we can’t really tell anything else about that $30 trillion dollars.

  • How does this number compare to the debt of other countries?
  • Is the number going up, or down?
  • How has this number changed over time?
  • What impact, if any, does this number have on the average American citizen?

Data visualization is the process of converting intimidating raw data into useful information by providing context and a purpose.

Before getting started

Imagine a coworker handing you an Excel or Google Spreadsheet full of facts and figures about the national debt in various countries. Does this mean you’re ready to jump right in and start making a chart?

Not quite. Before starting any visualization, there are four preparatory steps to take first.

Identify your audience

Before creating a visualization related to the United States national debt, it’s worth researching what your audience already knows about the topic. If your visual is set to appear in USA Today, your average reader probably knows very little about the national debt, and would benefit from quite a bit of background information to understand your chart.

On the other hand, designing a visual for the American Economic Review means that your audience likely brings a more sophisticated understanding of both the national debt and economics in general. Providing too much background information could bore your audience.

Decide on your story

Now that you’ve identified your audience, think about what you want them to do after encountering your visual. Many visualizations are designed to help viewers understand complex data, which would certainly be the case with most visualizations regarding the national debt.

Some visualizations are designed to evoke an emotional response. The Poppy Field Project uses the poppy, a symbol of war remembrance since World War I, to represent the number of deaths in each war over the course of a century.

Some visualizations, such as the illustrations of Mona Chalabi, are intended to spark anger or call for political change.

Double-check your data

The third step to take before starting a visualization is making sure you’ve tracked your data to its original source, and that you’ve checked the source is a reputable one.

Questions to ask when reviewing data include

  • What methods were used in obtaining the data?
  • How large was the sample size?
  • Is this the most recent data available?

A Hubspot article called How to Find Accurate and Compelling Data lists a number of reliable data sources.

Choose the right amount of data

Knowing your audience and your story should help you decide on the correct amount of data to provide. If your goal is to illustrate how the United States national debt has changed over time, comparisons to the debt of other countries aren’t really relevant, and should be left out of your chart.

It’s worth considering the context in which your chart will be seen. If your chart will be shared independently on social media, it’s critical the visualization can be understood on its own. If you’re creating a chart for a blog, however, it’s possible you’ll have a little more space to introduce some of your more advanced concepts and explain how your calculations were made.

items.title: Bar Charts, Histograms, and Pie Charts
items.content:
Bar Charts

A bar chart uses rectangular bars to make numerical comparisons between independent categories of data. The larger the rectangle, the greater the value represented.

Bar charts can be oriented horizontally or vertically. Sometimes vertically oriented charts are referred to as column charts to distinguish them from horizontal bar charts, though this terminology isn't universal.

For the most part, the horizontal and vertical orientations can be used interchangeably, although horizontal bar charts allow room for longer category labels.

Bar chart best practices

  • Bar charts show comparisons. Which group or individual performed best? Which data point appeared most frequently?
  • Your numeric axis (the y-axis, in the case of a vertical chart) should start at zero. Otherwise the visualization distorts the comparison being made.

  • Avoid 3D effects. This is an important rule data visualization in general. 3D effects make it harder for users to understand any visual comparison.

Histograms

At a glance, histograms look a lot like vertical bar charts, with the most obvious difference being that the rectangular bars in a histogram have no space separating one another.

However, the true difference lies in the type of data being displayed. Bar charts display discrete categories of data. If your goal is to compare residential property sales in a variety of nearby towns, and the name of each town appears separately on the x-axis, that’s a good use case for a bar chart.

Histograms, on the other hand, show continuous data on the x-axis using ranges of numbers. Each range of numbers on the x-axis is called a bin. If we wanted to display our residential property sales based on property cost, we could create bins for properties costing less than £50K, between £50K and £100K, £100K and £150K, and so on.

Histogram best practices

  • It’s important to note that you can’t skip or reorder bins, or else your histogram gets confusing. If no homes had sold between £350K and £400K, for example, I would leave that bin empty but not delete it from my chart.

Pie Charts

A pie chart shows how a total amount is divided into parts. The size of each slice indicates a proportion of the whole.

Pie charts have a bit of a bad reputation amongst practitioners of data visualization. If you’re not careful with your chart, it’s easy to distort the story told by the data.

The above visual, taken from a presentation given by Steve Jobs at the 2008 Macworld Conference, places Apple’s share of the pie closest to the viewer and distorts the slice using 3D effects. The resulting chart makes Apple’s 19.5% market share appear larger than the 21.2% market share belonging to Other companies outside the top five.

Pie chart best practices

  • Your storytelling shouldn’t depend on comparing similarly sized slices. Since pie slices are presented at an angle, it’s difficult for viewers to meaningfully compare them. If communicating your story depends on comparing a 19.5% market share to a 21.2% market share, try a different visualization.
  • Limit the number of slices. The more pie slices you add, the smaller the individual slices get. This makes them hard to effectively label, and adds to the user’s cognitive load.
  • Your numbers must add up to 100%. In the pie chart representing US population by ethnicity below, the pie chart visualizes only 74% of the United States population, exaggerating the presence of each slice of the pie and creating a misleading visualization.

items.title: Line and Area Charts, Scatter Plots, and Maps
items.content:
Line and Area Charts

Line charts

Line charts show the change of data over a continuous time span. If you’re telling a story of trends in your data or changes in value over time, line charts can be an effective choice.

Line charts get their name from the straight line segments used to connect individual data points.

As seen above, line charts can make comparisons by adding additional lines. However, be cautious about making more than 3 or 4 comparisons in a single graph, as too many lines make a chart difficult to read.

While bar charts should always use axis labels starting at zero, with line charts labeling the axis depends on the data being used. For example, in 2015 a publication skeptical of climate change called The National Review tweeted out a chart suggesting average global temperatures haven’t changed much from 1880 through 2015.

However, the chart uses numeric axis labels ranging from zero degrees to 110 degrees, even though every number represented is between 55 and 60 degrees Fahrenheit. (If the Earth’s average global temperature ever approaches zero or 110 degrees Fahrenheit, you won’t be alive to read this.)

Using realistic axis labels for the given data tells a very different story:

Area charts

Area charts are extremely similar to line charts, except the area between the line and the x axis is filled in with color. When working with multiple data sets, area charts are not a good choice since the color of the top layer hides the layers underneath.

However, combining multiple data sets can be useful in a stacked area chart, which demonstrate how each individual member contributes to a whole over time.

Scatter Plots

A scatter plot is a chart that displays the values of two different variables as points so we can study the correlation, or strength of relationship, between the variables.

The terms we would use to describe the correlation and diameter in the above scatter plot would be positive, linear, and strong. As the diameter increases, so does the height, without too many outliers. Outliers are data points that don’t fit the general pattern. If an object measured for this graph had a diameter of 7 cm but a height of only 2 inches, that would be considered an outlier compared to the rest of the data. The more outliers found, the weaker the correlation between two variables.

An important warning often given with scatter plots is correlation does not equal causation. A scatter plot comparing monthly ice cream sales versus monthly swimsuit sales, for example, would likely demonstrate a positive, exponential, and strong correlation. (Exponential because sales of both wouldn’t gradually rise with each small uptick in temperature–rather, we’d see a huge climb during the warmest months.)

However, would a scatter plot like this prove the rise in ice cream sales caused the rise in swimsuit sales? No. Both increases in sales were caused by a third variable, the rise in temperature.

Maps

The visualizations we’ve covered so far have a fixed shape and strict presentation parameters. However, sometimes the story you’re telling involves geographic data. While you might convey election results with a bar chart, users will likely find your story more meaningful if you visualize the results by city, state, or county.

A common visualization choice is the choropleth map, in which existing geographic regions are colored in based on the frequency of a variable.

As demonstrated in the above graphic, choropleth maps are useful only when working with relative numbers. The map on the left uses absolute numbers to demonstrate that Los Angeles County has the most unemployed people in California, but that’s to be expected. Los Angeles County has more than 10 million residents, while some counties in Northeastern California have fewer than 10,000. It’s far more meaningful to visualize the unemployment rates per 100 people.

items.title: 🎬 Data Visualization | Information Design vs. Data Visualization
items.content:
Transcript

Hello, my name is Anwar and I'm part of the Product Design curriculum team here at Flatiron School. In this series of lectures, we'll be discussing data visualization. Data visualization sounds pretty similar to information design, but are they the same? Let's take a look. 

Digital and content marketer Erin McCoy defines data visualization as the translation of datasets into a meaningful and easy to understand visual medium. 

The Venn diagram on screen demonstrates how data analysis, data visualization, and information design overlap. So while data visualization involves some of the same skills as information design, it also requires being able to analyze data to find meaning. Data analysis is more of an exploratory art and tends to come first in the data visualization process before the more explanatory art of information design. 

So are infographics synonymous with data visualization? According to product designer Valina Chan, not quite. Infographics are subjective, telling a premeditated story to guide the audience to conclusions. Data visualizations are objective, letting the audience draw their own conclusions.

Now it's time for discussion.

  1. What aspects of information design are directly related to data visualization?
  2. Are any aspects less relevant?

items.title: 🎬 Data Visualization | Data Visualization Process
items.content:
Transcript

A client hands us a table or spreadsheet full of facts and figures. Are we ready to begin designing? Not yet. Let's examine the process designers go through when approaching a data visualization. Before you begin designing, you need to know who you're designing for. How familiar is your audience with your topic? 

What decisions are your audience responsible for making? Are they comfortable with a complex chart, or will they need a simple presentation? Do they need precise numbers or just a general idea of an overall trend? Also, consider the context in which your audience will encounter your visual. Is it part of a presentation or will they be able to interact with the data and apply filters? 

Next decide on the story you need to tell. Remember, more data isn't always better. Figure out what your audience needs to know and how you want them to respond after encountering your visualization. 

Let's look at some examples. In 2014, the Washington Post created an online visual colored by a gradient from light to dark blue that required a ton of vertical scrolling to view as it was nearly 17,000 pixels tall. Why? Officials were searching for the wreckage of a missing Malaysian airliner some 15,000 feet beneath the surface of the ocean. Since most people can't visualize what 15,000 feet looks like, the visual tells the story, "how deep is the ocean?" 

In 2018, the website 538 used a scatter plot to diagram California's annual precipitation and average temperature from 1895 to 2018. Why? To answer the question, "is California getting hotter and drier?" While the dots representing 1895 to 1999 are scattered at random. The dots representing 2000 through 2018 clearly trend towards hot and dry. 

Data journalist Mona Chalabi created a bar chart using various sizes of folded up $1 bills. Why? To tell a story of income inequality. For every $1 a white man earns, Native American and Hispanic women earn less than 60 cents. 

The third step in preparing to visualize a set of data is to double-check it. If you didn't gather your own data, you need to check where it came from. In Chalabi's case, she used the 2015 United States census report. If you can't find the original source of your data, if you're uncertain of the trustworthiness of the source, or if you're not sure what methods were used to gather the data, don't use it. 

Once you're certain you're working with trustworthy data, you need to choose just the right amount. Faced with a table of data, it might be tempting to use all of it A visual representing income inequality in the United States could include the number of children in each family, for example, as that information is available in the census report. But would that information have helped tell a clear story? Or just cluttered the visualization? 

Once you know your audience, decide on your story, double-check and prepare your data, you'll finally be ready to select the most meaningful and appropriate chart or graphic. 

Now it's time for discussion.

  1. When you encounter a data visualization, how do you decide whether or not to trust it?
  2. How can designers make sure the audience trusts their visualizations?

items.title: 🎬 Data Visualization | Types of Visualizations
items.content:
Transcript

As you might imagine, there are many types of visualizations to choose from. What considerations do designers use to select one? 

The first step in picking the right visualization is knowing who your audience is and what knowledge they already have. If your topic is baseball, for example, you would design differently for hardcore, stat-obsessed fantasy players than you would for casual fans who only tune in for the World Series. 

Next, you need to decide what story you want to tell your audience and what question your audience might have in mind that your visualization is intended to answer. With that in mind, let's look at some different chart types. 

Bar graphs show comparisons between different categories of data. If the four employees of my company respectively sold $400, $700, $500, and $1000 worth of goods this month, I could use a bar graph like the one on the left to compare their performances. When labeling the numeric axis of a bar graph, which in this case would be sales amounts in dollars, always start the axis at zero. Otherwise you risk distorting the comparison being made. Line graphs, on the other hand, show changes in data over time. If my team sold 20 units in January, 40 in February, 35 in March, 45 in April, and 65 in May, I could visualize my team's performance over these five months using a line graph like the one on the right. Unlike bar graphs, line graphs sometimes label a numeric axis starting with a number other than zero. It depends on what's appropriate for the type of data you're using. 

Scatter plots help users understand the correlation, or strength of relationship, between two different variables. If I were making paper airplanes and wanted to determine whether there was a relationship between the weight of the paper and the distance the airplane traveled, I could chart each paper airplane's weight and performance on a scatter plot. 

After diagramming the data, I would analyze the correlation between the variables. Looking at the scatter plot on the left, I would say the relationship is positive, since the dots create a path from the lower left to the upper right, and linear, since they form a straight line rather than a curved one. 

The correlation is somewhat weak, however, since lots of dots are outliers, meaning they don't follow the general pattern. A flow chart as seen on the right is a diagram that shows a step-by-step progression through a system or process. 

Pie charts show percentages of a whole. If 60% of my class got an A this term, 25% got a B, 10% got a C, and 5% got a D, I could visualize class performance using a pie chart, like the one on the left. Just make sure your numbers add up to 100%. When working with small sets of data, you can use pictogram charts, also known as pictographs, such as the one on the right. 

Pictographs reduce the amount of reading by using icons to represent data. If one of my employees sold 4 cars today and another sold 2, I could represent their performance by using 4 and 2 car icons, respectively. Pictographs don't work well with large data sets, however.

Venn diagrams use overlapping circles to represent the relationship between sets of data. A Gantt chart is a unique type of bar chart depicting a project schedule from start to finish. 

Hierarchy diagrams show hierarchical relationships progressing from top to bottom. These might be used to show the structure of a business organization, with a CEO at the top and upper management at the next level. Hierarchical diagrams also feature in information architecture in the form of site map diagrams. 

Maps help users visualize distribution, location, and impact of data in a geographic environment. 

There are many other types of visualizations not listed here. And you'll encounter others as you learn more about data visualization. The important thing to remember is don't select your visualization type first. Figure out what you want your audience to know, and how you'd like them to respond after viewing your visualization. 

Then make your choice from there. 

As for best practices while making your visualization, always keep your specific audience in mind. Create visual hierarchy to draw attention to the most important information, and label your visualization clearly. Aim for simplicity and conciseness, which also means only including the data you absolutely need to tell your story. 

And do provide hierarchy, context, and contrast with your color choice.

items.title: 🎬 Data Visualization | Accessible Visualizations
items.content:
Transcript

Do data visualizations have their own considerations when it comes to creating an accessible experience? Let's find out. As much as possible, use plain language when labeling your charts. When using industry-specific terminology, make sure that the terms you use are essential to understanding the data and appropriate for your audience's level of knowledge. 

Make sure the labels you create for your chart are clear, easy to read, and do an obvious job of labeling data points. Here we see a clearly labeled chart illustrating the effectiveness of Calls To Action within an email campaign in a particular week. 

The X axis is labeled based on the date, while the Y axis is labeled based on how many thousands of clicks each Call To Action received. The chart also has a legend indicating the blue line on the graph represents new accounts opened, and the green line represents unsubscriptions. So that's effective labeling. 

And yet I see a potential accessibility issue still lingering. Can you spot it? 

Here's an award-winning visualization called The Daily Routines of Famous Creative People. The labeling looks clear enough. We see the 24 hours of the day, as well as the sleep and creative work habits of a number of authors, musicians, and artists. 

Yet, I still believe there's an accessibility issue. Can you find it? 

If you mentioned color, great job. When applying color to data visualizations designers need to follow two rules. Don't rely on color alone to provide meaning. And do use sufficient color contrast. Each of the previous two charts relied solely on color to convey information. 

Onscreen we see two charts as viewed using colorblindness simulators. In the top chart, labeling the bars of the graph directly helps audiences who can't distinguish between the colors of the bars. In the pie chart at the bottom, a thin white separator aids viewers who can't distinguish between the low contrast colors used to color slices of the pie. 

What if users can't see your chart? Partner with developers to write an effective alt description that at the very least lists the type of the chart, describes the story being told by the data, and explains the reason for including the chart. Linking users to the original data source has two benefits. 

It makes your chart feel more trustworthy, and it provides an additional resource for audiences who can't see your chart. 

Here's a chart from the New York Times from 2015 labeled gun murders per 100,000 people. Our alt text might read, "bar chart of gun murders per 100,000 people where America's murder rate is six times worse than Canada and 30 times Australia". 

Now it's time for discussion.

  1. What is the greatest challenge designers face when creating accessible visualizations?
  2. What specific steps can designers take to make sure their charts are accessible?

items.title: Introducing Dashboards
items.content:
Dashboards show relevant information

Think about the role the dashboard serves in a car. Car dashboards tend to display information relevant to the everyday task of driving, such as the car’s speed, the engine temperature, and the amount of gas left.

In addition, car dashboards include warning indicators in situations that call for driver attention, such as low tire pressure or an overheating engine. It’s critical the dashboard uses warning icons that can be quickly understood so the driver doesn’t continue driving in unsafe conditions.

Similarly, dashboards in digital applications are meant to show users relevant data at a glance. Unlike most car dashboards, however, digital application dashboards are interactive, meaning you can start the user with a high-level overview and allow them to view more details with a tap or click.

Dashboard categories

Information management dashboards for businesses are known as BI (Business Intelligence) Dashboards. These typically come in three varieties:

  • Operational dashboards focus on real-time system status updates. Perhaps the best-known example is the Google Analytics Real-time dashboard, which offers details to website owners on the number of users and average engagement time, as well as insights on which campaigns inspire the most page visits.

    `
  • Analytical dashboards have features that allow for a deeper examination of the data presented. Analytical dashboards tend to be highly interactive and help data analysts analyze long term trends.

  • Unlike the highly specific nature of analytical dashboards, Strategic Dashboards limit their view to measuring performance against a set of key performance indicators (KPIs).

Not every dashboard is aimed at business intelligence, however. As a user, you may have encountered Google’s Digital Wellbeing or Apple’s Screen Time, two apps meant to offer users control over their smartphone usage.

items.title: Dashboard Design: Best Practices
items.content:
Know your user

Know your user isn’t a very surprising rule for a product designer. But since digital application dashboards can easily provide an overwhelming amount of information or options, it’s important to use research to gain a clear understanding of user needs.

  • How does your user plan to interact with your dashboard?
  • What information does your user view as of primary importance? Secondary?
  • On what devices will your user be accessing the dashboard?
  • What actions will your user take after viewing the dashboard?

Choose the right visualization

When converting raw data into a meaningful visualization, make sure you’re aware of the story the user is looking for the data to tell, and choose the most logical visualization.

  • Pie charts demonstrate parts of a whole
  • Bar charts compare data points
  • Scatter plots examine the correlation between variables
  • Line charts examine trends over time

Lead with big, bold numbers

Don’t present too much detail up front. Knowing your user means prioritizing the information that’s most critical to your users.

If users need more information than what’s offered at a glance, offer them the ability to drill down with a click or a tap.

Apply color meaningfully

Too much color doesn’t just create visual noise–it can also create a confusing experience. Keep your color application strategic, meaningful, and minimal.

And as always, don’t forget about accessibility. If you’re conveying meaning only through the use of color, some users won’t be able to make sense of your information.

Group related data

When dealing with datasets that relate to each other or are easier to understand when seen together, group them together visually.

Allow customization

Whenever possible, allowing users to customize views will help them make the most useful features and information even more prominent–provided the customization options don’t interfere with your application’s navigation pattern or visual consistency.

items.title: Sorting and Filtering
items.content:
Why sort and filter?

Whether you’re creating a dashboard, a search results page, or a list of products on an e-commerce site, your users are bound to sometimes find themselves faced with a daunting amount of information. A good portion of that information will be irrelevant to the user’s goal.

Sorting allows users to order a list of content based on attributes they care most about.

Filtering allows users to reduce a vast list of content down to a smaller list relevant to their needs and interests.

If your product is likely to provide users with large lists of content, sorting and filtering isn’t an either/or proposition. Users depend on both to find the information most meaningful to them.

Sorting best practices

Use a predictable pattern

For users to understand their sorting options, make sure your sorting interface is labeled appropriately, uses a familiar pattern (most often a dropdown menu), and is placed immediately above sortable content where users will expect to find it.

Provide useful defaults

Alphabetical sorting is rarely useful, unless you’re confident users know the exact name of what they’re looking for. An alphabetical list of states or countries is fine, but an alphabetical list of unfamiliar product names isn’t helpful to most users.

Many interfaces default to Most Relevant, meaning the product is prioritizing the content most relevant to the user’s search term or to this particular category of information.

Additional sorting options

Users expect to be able to sort numerical categories of data, such as price, from highest to lowest as well as lowest to highest.

It often makes sense to allow users to sort content based on temporal categories (related to time) as well. This might mean placing the newest results first and the oldest results last. An auction website like eBay allows users to sort by which auction ends soonest, while users of an air travel website can sort by flight length.

Filtering best practices

Customize

No two filtering experiences are quite alike. To reference our previous example, attempting to provide the same set of filters for an auction website and an air travel website would make little sense. Filter categories should be carefully crafted for the particular content, and category names should be tested on users.

If your product offers a broad variety of content, providing custom filters for each category of content is a lot of work, but it results in a better experience. Etsy, for example, provides the same set of filters regardless of whether users search for patio furniture or pet clothing, which can get a bit frustrating.

Expedia, on the other hand, provides a totally different set of filters for hotels than it does for flight searches.

Design carefully for mobile

While many products place filtering options in a sidebar next to the list of results on the desktop, on the mobile screen there isn’t space for a sidebar. Many mobile products instead expand filtering menus to fill the entire screen.

However, even when expanding filters to the full screen, designers need to provide generous spacing so users can successfully tap each interface item with their finger. WCAG success criterion 2.5.5 suggests that interface target sizes are inaccessible unless they’re a minumum of 44 square pixels.

Designers of mobile filters often minimize scrolling by implementing the collapsed accordion pattern, in which users collapse irrelevant categories and uncollapse meaningful ones.

Prioritize

The more frequently used filters should be placed at the top, where users will notice them right away. This is particularly true on mobile, where scrolling down through a long filtering menu can be a challenge.

Place more general categories such as brand name, price, and size towards the top. More specialized filters that might appeal to expert users can be placed lower on the page.

items.title: 🎬 Designing Dashboards | What is a Dashboard?
items.content:
Transcript

Hello. My name is Anwar and I'm part of the Product Design curriculum team here at Flatiron School. In this series of lectures we'll be discussing designing dashboards. 

So what is a dashboard? According to Stephen Few, author of a book called Information Dashboard Design, a dashboard is a visual display of the most important information needed to achieve one or more objectives, consolidated and arranged on a single screen so the information can be monitored at a glance. 

Here's an example. The YouTube studio dashboard brings up the most meaningful creator stats at a glance, including watch time, views, subscribers, top videos, and latest activity. 

Great dashboards communicate information quickly, display information clearly and efficiently, show trends and changes in data over time, and are easily customizable. 

When designing a dashboard, it's impossible to make all the data a user could possibly need available upfront. Instead, it's critical to identify the most important information and create a clear visual hierarchy to make that information understandable, meaningful, and usable. Provide additional links and filters so users have the opportunity to drill down for more details.

items.title: 🎬 Designing Dashboards | Types of Dashboards
items.content:
Transcript

 Not every dashboard serves the same function. Let's take a look at different types of dashboards. Operational dashboards are the most traditional and commonly used type of dashboard, presenting real time data of daily business operations. The main purpose of operational dashboards is to keep track of and evaluate how well ongoing processes and short-term operations are working. 

An analytical dashboard presents data trends over time to help users make better decisions about the future.  While the initial view of an analytical dashboard tends to show data over months, quarters, or years, analytical dashboards are also typically highly interactive to enable deeper analysis. Analytical dashboards supply a business with a comprehensive overview of its data operations. 

Strategic dashboards let the user track their main strategic goals via KPIs, or key performance indicators, as well as OKRs, or objectives and key results. Strategic dashboards are often used to compare the performance of individual departments against an overall longterm strategy and do so by comparing the current working period against past performance. 

Whether the dashboard you're designing is an operational, analytical, or strategic dashboard, you'll want to make sure your dashboard can adapt to the needs of the person using it. Two ways to do so are through personalization and customization. While these two terms sound similar, personalization describes content and functionality that matches specific user needs or interests with no effort from the user. 

If a dashboard uses geolocation to present information relevant to a user's current location, or adapts the display of information based on the user's role or previous activity, the system would be automatically personalizing the user's experience. Customization, on the other hand, is performed by the user. 

In a customized experience, the user can choose what they want to see, or set preferences for how information is organized or displayed. 

Now it's time for discussion.

  1. What information would you need from users to determine the right type of dashboard to design?
  2. What methods would you use to determine the ideal mix of presentation and customization options?

items.title: 🎬 Designing Dashboards | Dashboards & Data Storytelling
items.content:
Transcript

What is the connection between dashboard design and data storytelling? Let's find out. 

Dashboards are a form of data communication. Data storytelling is a collection of skills and concepts that help improve data communication. To be effective, a dashboard needs to communicate clearly to its intended audience. It needs to be clear, concise, engaging, and organized. Dashboard should provide a consistent view of key metrics and trends that are important to the audience and should reflect the audience's priorities. 

Telling an effective story with data using a dashboard can feel structurally similar to composing a three act play. We start by setting context. What can the audience learn from this data? Why is this meaningful? And why is this information credible? Next comes the heart of the story. The audience may need to be guided through the data to find insights relevant to them. 

Finally during the resolution, the audience takes action. This could be a direct action, something that can be done right now based on the data. Or it might be an indirect action, in which the data helps the user make better decisions in the future. 

In other words, storytelling means more than just presenting data. Dashboards should set a context to explain why a chart is relevant, describe the chart so users can understand how to interpret it, guide the flow so users understand how to move forward, and highlight insights and actions so users remember key takeaways and have enough information to make thoughtful decisions. 

The individual metrics presented by your dashboard are the characters in your story. Deciding which metrics to emphasize in a data story can be complex, but the decision should be made based on the needs and priorities of your audience. Displaying only a few metrics at a time makes your story easier to understand, and makes it easier for your audience to identify the heroes or villains–that is, the good or bad data points based on the user's strategic goals. 

Now it's time for discussion.

  • What visual storytelling components could you use in your dashboard to make the story accessible to people outside of your organization?

items.title: 🎬 Designing Dashboards | Dashboard Design Pitfalls
items.content:
Transcript

What pitfalls should designers avoid when creating dashboards? When designing dashboards, marketing strategist Eleanor Taylor says the challenge is not to add new features, but to add value and power to products without adding any complexity. In other words, don't add features just to have them.  Calculate the value each feature offers the user, and whether you're helping users answer key questions and navigate data to find meaning. 

Perhaps you've heard of the five second test, a rapid usability test in which participants are given only five seconds to view a design before answering questions about what they remember. This technique measures how quickly a design communicates a message. If users can't remember how their most important metrics are performing after viewing your dashboard for five seconds, that's a good indication you've made it too cluttered. 

Use caution when adding animations and 3D effects to your dashboard visualizations. Motion should be purposeful, indicating a direction of change or leading users towards the answer to their question. 3D effects should be applied sparingly, if at all, as they can make charts harder to read and distort comparisons within datasets. 

Color should also be applied purposefully. Too many colors creates visual noise and makes your content hard to read and understand. Also, as with any data visualization, avoid relying on color alone to communicate meaning. 

While designers should strive for a clean dashboard layout with plenty of white space and effective visual hierarchy, be aware of making your design so minimal that your information lacks context. Users need enough labels to find meaning and spot trends in the data, as well as to indicate what their interactive options are on each screen. 

Just as with any visual design, you can't make everything on a dashboard screen important. Guide the user's eye to key information. Embrace progressive disclosure: reserve less important information and advanced features for secondary screens. 

Lack of contrast will lead to users struggling to accurately interpret the information in front of them. While you'll want to make sure your colors meet contrast standards outlined by the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines, you'll also need to make sure you've applied contrast meaningfully to your design so users don't miss the point of your visual.

items.title: Presenting to Different Audiences
items.content:
Presenting is a core design skill

“I’d rather have a good designer who can present well than a great designer who can’t....

Work that can’t be sold is as useless as the designer who can’t sell it.”

Mike Monteiro, 13 Ways Designers Screw Up Client Presentations

Presenting is hard work. In fact, some design professionals say it’s the toughest part of the job.

Taking a user-centered approach to your presentation is a design problem, like many others you have tackled up to this point. As you have learned, design is only as good as your ability to communicate it. It takes work to craft the story of your project and to tell that story in an engaging and professional manner that is appropriate for your audience.

As a designer, you might be expected to present your work and decisions to a variety of stakeholders, including upper management, clients and internal team members. When you present your work to stakeholders, it’s important to keep your audience in mind to make sure that you’re conveying information in the most effective way.

If you’re presenting to developers, be sure to target specific deliverables that communicate how the project needs to be built within the determined constraints. If you’re meeting with the Chief Financial Officer (CFO), highlight important data points and discuss the initial cost/eventual return on investment (ROI) of your designs. Speaking to your audience can go a long way in growing your stakeholder-designer relationship and increasing their buy-in.

In any presentation, your primary objective is usually to communicate with your audience effectively. But what does that mean? Communication consists of sender, transmission, reception, receiver, and noise. Your job is to amplify the message signal and minimize the noise. Every element of a design presentation should be tuned to reduce interference and boost signal quality.

Plan for Your Audience

To communicate as effectively as possible, designers should focus on the audience as they would a user when designing a product. To get the process of planning a presentation kicked off, a designer may consider some of the following questions.

What does your audience care about?

Tying your designs back to business goals shows executives that you understand what’s in it for them (and the business). By showing a strong correlation between a business objective (like increasing conversions) with customer expectations of your design, you’ll make a strong argument for the value of your team’s efforts.

Think about areas of agreement between your design ideas and the client’s business goals and build the presentation from there.

What does your audience already know?

How much background knowledge or context will your audience need to understand what you will present? Take a minute to set the stage, but keep it to about a minute. Call out who you worked with, what the goal of the project is, and what you’re going to show them right off the bat.

Also, be conscious of terminology. If you are presenting to non-designers, they may not be as familiar with specific concepts and terms.

What is the framework for evaluating success?

What is the framework for evaluating success? Remind the audience what success looks like. If your audience already agrees with the scorecard then your ideas will be received better. Why? Because you designed with that evaluation in mind.

Even if your ideas are critiqued or rejected, you will work collaboratively towards a solution because you all agree on how to evaluate success.

What research findings best support your design decisions?

If you’ve done ethnographic research, created personas, user stories, or journey maps, then you have a lot of material to pull from for storytelling. You can use direct quotes, images, animation, and video to keep your audience focused on the humans in your human-centered designs.

Don’t talk about your users like a distant third-party. Keep your audience focused on how user input drove your design decisions.

Presentation Best Practices

  • Break the problem into smaller pieces. Quick wins can be used to get buy in for the next chunk of the project.
  • Keep your slides lean and varied. Don’t use a paragraph when a sentence will do. Don’t use a sentence if a short phrase or single word will work. The slides should reinforce what you say to the audience, not replace it.
  • Rehearse, and rehearse again. Before presenting, do a dry run in front of a peer who will be honest and provide constructive feedback. Ask for very pointed feedback, including if your message is clear, you summarize well, and if you’re missing anything.
  • Show your passion and personality. Don’t hide behind the laptop or read a script. Engage the room and use body language to direct audience attention.
  • Use your mistakes. If an actor makes a mistake on stage, the audience is usually unaware as long as the scene continues uninterrupted. When you make a mistake, don't draw too much attention to it.
  • Be flexible. You should be ready to answer questions about your work. Take feedback graciously, but don’t be afraid to redirect if the feedback focuses on the wrong elements.
  • Shape audience feedback. A room full of stakeholders likely has no idea what type of feedback a design team is seeking. Consider letting the audience know what type of input you’re looking for:
    • Do our designs reflect your brand?
    • Do our designs reflect your users’ needs?
    • Do our designs align with your current business strategy?

items.title: Storytelling in Design Presentations
items.content:
Freytag’s Pyramid and Dramatic Structure

In the mid-19th century, German author Gustav Freytag observed that classical Greek tragedies and Shakespearean dramas tend to have a common narrative arc. Freytag’s observations on the five key stages of a dramatic story are now known as Freytag’s pyramid.

Freytag’s pyramid is divided into five parts:

  • Exposition: introduce key information, start the main conflict of the story
  • Rising action: explore the story’s conflict leading up to the climax
  • Climax: an emotional apex and a turning point which changes the story
  • Falling action: the aftermath of the climax, in which conflicts begin to resolve
  • Resolution: where loose ends are tied up and the final outcome is made clear

This same structure can add drama to a UX presentation. Designers give their project a clear introduction, emphasize the conflict standing between the design team and project goals, build towards a climax, and reveal takeaways at the conclusion.

Know your audience first

The purpose of any great story is to transform. Even in a job interview, you want to transform your audience from frustrated skeptics with a UX problem, into excited optimists who believe you’re the answer to their woes. – Alexa Harrison, Designlab

Before you begin sketching out your story, make sure you’re aware of your audience’s needs. You should be able to answer the following questions:

  • What are my audience’s motivations and goals?
  • What blockers are presenting my audience from reaching their goals?
  • What prior knowledge do they bring to the presentation?
  • How do we want the audience to respond to the presentation?

The answer to the last two questions in particular will shape the work you do during the exposition and resolution stage of your presentation. The more background your audience brings to the presentation, the briefer your introduction can be. And you can shape your conclusion according to the types of questions and responses you’re hoping to receive.

Exposition

The exposition stage of your presentation covers the following:

  • A brief summary of the project
  • The team that worked on the project, and the role of each team member
  • The motivations behind the project. What problem were you trying to solve?
  • Background information informing the project, including assumptions that needed challenging

Don’t forget to use the project introduction to remind your audience why they’re here. If you wait until the climax to inform stakeholders of the value of your presentation, they might have tuned out by then. Include a brief statement summarizing the goal, value, and key insight of your design project early on.

Rising Action

The design process used to explore the problem and test out solutions contribute to the rising action of your presentation. Briefly explain what happened at each stage of the design process. If you followed the five steps of the Design Thinking Process, present deliverables that demonstrate what you learned while Empathizing, Defining, Ideating, Prototyping, and Testing.

While the design process tends to be iterative rather than linear, keep your presentation building towards its climax. Minimize details that don’t contribute to the overall flow of your story, or ones that don’t represent major insights that lead toward your ultimate conclusion.

Climax

If your audience were to only remember 1 or 2 details from your presentation, which details would you choose? Your climax should be a memorable turning point from your design project, one that determined the final direction and outcome.

Teo Yu Siang of Interaction Design Foundation suggests the climax of your story might be

  • A tough decision your team had to make
  • An unexpected user insight uncovered through user research–one that forced you to change the direction of the project
  • A sudden or time-sensitive challenge you solved
  • A novel idea or solution to a key problem

Falling Action

If the climax is a key insight your team uncovered or an important decision your team made, your falling action should be informed by that insight or decision.

Your later iterations and high-fidelity deliverables should reflect the research, insights, and decision-making conducted earlier in the design process. Your audience should understand these deliverables as directly influenced by the climax of your story.

Resolution

Your conclusion should reflect back on the initial goals, provide actionable next steps, and set up an opportunity for audience feedback and questions.

Note that your story presentation can feel successful even if your project missed its mark. Perhaps you began your design project operating under an assumption that user research proved false. In that case, you can still

  • Reflect on your process
  • Review any lessons that might shape your next round of design explorations
  • Highlight the benefits of your project, even if it didn’t lead to a solution. (Perhaps you saved your stakeholders money by convincing them not to pursue a feature nobody needs.)

items.title: 🎬 Storytelling and Presenting | Storytelling 101
items.content:
Transcript

Hello, My name is Anwar and I'm part of the Product Design curriculum team here at Flatiron School. In this series of lectures we'll be discussing storytelling and presenting. Let's start with storytelling 101. Fantasy novelist Brandon Sanderson says that the purpose of a storyteller is not to tell you how to think, but to give you questions to think upon. Which is an interesting way to look at storytelling,

but how can we apply that idea to design presentations? Let's start with a discussion prompt. How do you define an effective story?

First, we need to recognize that design presentations are meant to be customized based on your understanding of your audience. Who is your audience? Are they stakeholders? Designers? Engineers? Or a mixture? What is important to them? What knowledge level do they bring to your presentation? When presentations fall flat, it's because the presenter didn't compel the audience to listen.

Add drama by approaching your presentation as a narrative. Make the problem you were trying to solve immediately clear. Highlight the challenges you overcame, and reach a memorable conclusion. When building your presentation as a story, emphasize conflict. What pain points faced the user? What challenges stood in your way as you attempted to define the problem, alleviate pain points, or test a solution?

Create a sense of continuity in your narrative using foreshadowing and echoing techniques. Foreshadowing gives an indication or hint of something important happening later in the story, while echoing means referring back to a lesson learned earlier. Transitions link one piece of the story to the next and keep the audience eager to learn what's coming on the next set of slides. Think of your favorite action or suspense novel. Each chapter ends with an unanswered question, making it hard for the reader to put the book down until they've discovered the answer. "Show, don't tell" is common storytelling advice. Instead of explaining what happened, allow the reader to experience the story through actions, visuals, and appeals to the reader's emotions.

Keep the number of words per slide to a minimum, and instead choose the graphics, charts, user quotes, and verbal anecdotes that will tell the same story, but more vividly. Common storytelling techniques include the hero's journey or monomyth in which an adventurer goes on a journey, overcomes a crisis, and returns home changed or transformed.

This is one reason why many design presentations end with what the designer would do differently next time based on what they learned from this project. The converging ideas method shows the audience how different approaches or ways of thinking ultimately merge to form one single, stronger idea.

A false start story is when you begin to tell a seemingly predictable story before unexpectedly disrupting it and beginning all over again. This might happen when an insight uncovered during research or user testing led to a total change in project direction. In medias res is a technique for beginning a narrative in the heat of the action before returning to the beginning and explaining how you got there. Used appropriately, this can hook your audience from the beginning. Just be careful not to reveal too much of the project's conclusion too early. In medias res works best when beginning shorter presentations, as taking too long to return to the crisis point can frustrate your audience.

items.title: 🎬 Storytelling and Presenting | Creating a Presentation
items.content:
Transcript

What goes into an effective presentation? Let's find out. Author and motivational speaker Lily Walters says the success of your presentation will be judged not by the knowledge you send, but by what the listener receives. In other words, simply documenting a successful design project isn't enough. 

You need to convince your audience your work matters to them, and deliver your most important insights in a way they'll remember later. 

Before we look at some common components of an effective presentation, here's another discussion prompt. What makes a presentation compelling? Is your answer different for online presentations versus when you're in the room with the speaker? 

Let's discuss what goes into an effective presentation. You'll want to use your early slides to let your audience know what you're presenting and why your presentation matters to them. What was your role? Who worked with you? What was the main problem you were trying to solve? As you move forward, explain the design process you took your project through, including the motivation for each step. Summarize key insights learned at each stage using a combination of prominent text, numbers, iconography, and visuals so the audience doesn't have to struggle to understand what's important. 

Finally, conclude your presentation with the single most important takeaway. Include what you've learned and where you'd like the project to head next. 

As you design your slides, keep the number of words per slide to a minimum. Apple CEO Steve Jobs famously rehearsed his presentations so thoroughly that his slides often consisted of a single word or a single visual. If your audience is busy reading your slides, they're probably not listening. 

Designing visually compelling slides isn't enough on its own. A conversational tone keeps the audience engaged. Just as you can stress important takeaways visually, you can do the same with your voice. Now bear in mind that sounding both conversational and authoritative isn't something that comes naturally for most people. 

The more you rehearse your presentation beforehand, the more confident you'll feel and sound. Finally, allow time for audience questions at the end, and do your best to anticipate questions your audience might ask you as part of your preparation. 

As you explain your design process, keep in mind the level of knowledge your audience brings to the presentation. A room full of designers will recognize common design deliverables, so there's no need to define them. Just jump right in to why you did what you did and what you learned. Stakeholders, on the other hand, might need a bit more background information. And developers will be interested to hear your thoughts on implementing your designs, and whether you've kept technological feasibility in mind. 

Don't forget the story you tell should constantly reinforce the reason you're giving the presentation. Are you sharing your vision? Educating the audience? Reporting on your progress? Trying to persuade your audience to follow a particular direction? Don't get so caught up in small details that your audience loses track of the big picture. 

Finally, remember to respect your audience's attention span. Make sure your presentation is designed for the time slot you've been given and doesn't go over time. Vary your presentation methods a bit by saying more about some slides and less about others. Build in checks for understanding by asking questions of your audience or allowing them opportunities to participate.

items.title: 🎬 Storytelling and Presenting | Designing Your Slides
items.content:
Transcript

Let's talk about strategies for designing your slides. The slide on the left contains far too many words. Don't forget our storytelling advice: show, don't tell. If your topic is the glorious rings of Saturn, including a recognizable photo of Saturn allows you to remove a ton of text. 

This is also a reminder of the benefits of a well-rehearsed presentation. The more confident you feel about how you're going to describe each slide verbally, the fewer words you'll need on screen. Here we've removed even more text by identifying the most important takeaways within the body copy and visualized them using large text and iconography. 

Even if your audience ignores the body text, the bold heading and highlighted key points give them plenty to remember. 

Remember the five second test? Try it with the slide on the left. I'd be surprised if you remember much of anything after five seconds, apart from the photo of the planet Venus. The designer hasn't done the work to determine what information is most important, 

and has instead placed the burden on the viewer. How about the same five second test with the slide on the right? Cutting away irrelevant data and providing a visualization with big bold numbers makes the information far easier to recall. 

These two slides contain the same information presented in roughly the same way, but it's much easier to read the slide on the right thanks to the generous white space. White space reduces visual tension and allows the viewer the opportunity to concentrate on one visual at a time. 

 Creating transitions between sections of your presentation with a big, bold visual is helpful for a number of reasons. This technique captures attention while at the same time allowing both the audience and the presenter a few seconds to catch their breath before diving into a new set of information. 

Varying your slide layouts also keeps your presentation from growing too dull or repetitive. 

As you design your slides, be thinking about how your audience will receive your presentation. Audiences for virtual presentations using video conferencing software generally have shorter attention spans and face more distractions than in-person audiences. On the other hand, if your presentation is being sent directly to your audience, meaning you won't be there to provide verbal context, you'll have to make each slide just a bit wordier so the slides can speak for themselves.

items.title: Presenting Research Insights
items.content:
Avoid sharing raw data

Research is an indispensable part of the product design process. Using quantitative research methods such as A/B testing, analytics, and desirability studies yield a lot of numbers that might inform future design decisions. Similarly, qualitative research methods such as card sorting, user interviews, and user testing offer valuable feedback from test participants.

However, data in its raw form doesn’t make for a particularly compelling presentation. Think of the competitive analysis matrix: while a spreadsheet is a useful tool for taking notes on your competitors, stakeholders who didn’t participate in the competitive analysis don’t want to spend time reading your spreadsheet. They want to hear your insights on potential strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats within the marketplace, and they want those insights delivered in a digestible manner.

Explain your research methods

How did you gather your data? Briefly summarizing the goals of your user research and the methods you use lends credibility to your findings.

Prioritize your findings

Instead of presenting all the findings from a study, focus on the 3 or 4 key insights your audience should remember after the presentation. Any more than that, and you risk overwhelming your audience.

Limiting the number of insights presented might mean omitting some of the research data you worked hard to collect, but that’s alright. Hang on to that data in case someone asks for it. But unless the data helps you convey a meaningful story to stakeholders, leave it out.

Tailor your findings to your audience

Not every audience will be interested in the same aspects of your research. Designers and developers might want a detailed breakdown of pain points facing your audience, while upper management might be satisfied with a broader overview.

If necessary, create multiple versions of your presentation depending on your expected audience.

Visualize your findings

To create effective slides for your research presentation, use charts and graphs to visualize your data.

Some things to keep in mind while designing your slides:

  • Use consistent fonts, colors, icons, layout, and spacing for each slide
  • Don’t try to fit multiple visuals or multiple thoughts on the same screen. One idea per slide.
  • Use as few words as possible per slide to convey meaning

Include user quotes

If your research project involved speaking with users, letting users state the problem in their own words is a powerful tool. You can highlight pull quotes, or even include videos from testing sessions.

Source: Creating an engaging user research presentation

Provide actionable recommendations

For every problem uncovered in your research, offer a recommendation for a next step, whether conducting additional discovery or implementing a specific fix to the user interface.

Don’t forget to connect your recommendation to the goal of the research project. Your suggestions should offer tangible value to both the business and the user.

items.title: 🎬 Presenting Research | Value of Presenting Research
items.content:
Transcript

Hello, my name is Anwar and I'm part of the Product Design curriculum team here at Flatiron School. In this series of lectures we'll be discussing presenting research. Let's start by examining why presenting the results from your research is valuable. UX researcher Nikki Anderson says it doesn't matter how good the findings are if you aren't able to communicate them effectively with your team. From learning about data visualization, you might recall that data–in other words, raw, unorganized facts and numbers–is useless until you provide it with context, organization, and a purpose. 

The same is true when presenting to team members and stakeholders. Until you convert your research findings into actionable information, your raw data lacks value. 

When you provide raw data, when your presentation is too lengthy or too disorganized, or when your findings aren't obvious and actionable, your research gets ignored. 

So what does an actionable research presentation consist of? First of all, reminding stakeholders of why the research was conducted gives context to your data. What were you hoping to find? What value does this research project provide to the business? 

Before starting a research project, you should have a clear hypothesis or testable assumption in mind about what you're expecting to happen. When presenting the results of your research, remind your audience about the assumptions made about target users. Did your research project confirm or contradict these assumptions? 

Your research presentation should include a brief description of the methods used to collect your data. How many users did you interview or observe? What were the pros and cons of each method? Keep this portion of your presentation concise and appropriate to your audience. Stakeholders don't need to hear every last detail of your research methodology, 

just enough to get a sense of the thoroughness and effectiveness of your approach. 

Most importantly, never present all the data you've gathered, as this wastes the audience's time and your energy.  Instead, highlight the findings that will matter most to your audience and inspire meaningful action. 

When highlighting key insights from your research data, apply the same principles as you would to any data visualization. Look for patterns in the data and call attention to the insights that are most relevant to the problems facing the business and the user. Present big bold takeaways designed to have a maximum impact on decision-making, even if that decision is to conduct additional research. 

Now it's time for discussion.

  1. What are some effective ways to make sure the research findings you present align with your audience's interests?
  2. Would your answer change depending on who is in your audience?

items.title: 🎬 Presenting Research | Sharing Research Findings
items.content:
Transcript

Let's take a closer look at some best practices for sharing research findings. You'll want to get started by providing context for your audience by reminding them of the following. Who participated in this research project? When did the research occur? Why does this research matter right now? What were we hoping to learn? 

Refer back to this final question–what were we hoping to learn–frequently. Any research data that isn't relevant to the project goal should be left out of your presentation. 

Next, briefly summarize your team's research methodology. Take a moment to remind your audience of what research activities took place, why these methods were chosen, how they were conducted, and who participated. When planning your next research project, by the way, don't forget the value of participatory design. 

 If it's possible to bring stakeholders to research activities, or even invite their participation, they'll feel engaged and offer feedback along the way. 

When presenting relevant data, command attention with big, bold facts and figures that are easy to read and easy to remember.  Then provide pertinent details or evidence to support your main points. The data you highlight should be connected back to your original hypothesis and should shine a spotlight on recurring trends and themes. Visualize data so your audience can make sense of it quickly. 

Letting users state insights in their own words is often more powerful than stating them yourself. You can include user quotes in your presentation, or even short videos from research sessions. 

 In fact, one method of sharing insights called Atomic Research insists on pairing every insight with a short video of a target user talking about or demonstrating the experience. In Atomic Research, reports and slide decks are replaced with individual insights called nuggets that are linked to supporting video evidence and tagged by category. 

Your user research efforts may produce a variety of deliverables, including a competitive analysis, personas, user journey maps, affinity diagrams, and storyboards. However, these deliverables don't all need to be in your presentation. Before deciding to include a research artifact, remind yourself of who your audience is and what they want to know. 

If the deliverable doesn't help your audience understand the user, or the product, or the problem statement, leave it out. Include a brief summary of the findings instead. 

When concluding your presentation, circle back to your original set of questions. Did your team learn what it needed to? Of your testable assumptions, which were validated, and which were invalidated? In addition, include suggestions for what should happen next. How might this research impact future decision-making? 

Is additional research needed? 

If you're wondering whether it's okay to admit shortcomings of your research project, the answer is yes. All user research methods have potential drawbacks. If your research took place remotely, for example, you might have a limited understanding of the participant's use context. Be honest about what you didn't learn, as stakeholders are more inclined to trust you when you are completely transparent.

items.title: 🎬 Presenting Research | What to do
items.content:
Transcript

Let's take a look at a few example slides, starting with suggestions of what to do when designing a user research presentation. Do call out key quantitative data and emphasize its correlation with qualitative data. 

Do add context where applicable. While keeping slides simple and concise helps get the point across to viewers, provide additional context if it makes the insight more meaningful. Adding just a bit of contextual information to a slide is particularly helpful if the presentation will be shared digitally, meaning you won't be there to explain the slides verbally. 

Do say more with less. Omit unnecessary words, decorative elements, and visuals that don't add to your storytelling. Unnecessary elements distract from the information you are trying to provide. 

Do add a personal touch or human element. Including quotes, photos, or videos involving the target users interviewed can make your content not only informative, but also relatable and emotional. By themselves, numbers can feel cold. Personalization can add a sense of warmth and help create a sense of connection between your audience and the insights you're sharing. 

Do apply a consistent visual identity to your slides and pay attention to rhythm, white space, and grid. 

How about some examples of what not to do? 

Don't create a wall of text. The more words you add to a slide, the less likely anyone will read it. 

Don't crowd information into your slide with no consideration for white space or visual hierarchy. And while bulleted lists are an excellent way to present key insights, they shouldn't contain complete sentences. Include a few keywords per bulleted item, then supply additional context or explanation verbally. 

Don't present multiple ideas in the same slide. Rather than presenting an insight and a supporting user quote on the same slide, separate them onto two slides so viewers can concentrate on one idea at a time. Can you think of any other ways to improve this slide? 

I'm looking at the main insight, which reads, "Before COVID, users enjoyed traveling globally to broaden their horizons connect with diverse groups of people, and immerse themselves in these rich cultures. They are longing to book and enjoy these immersive cultural experiences in their local, domestic, and virtual spaces." 

That's a lot of words. Try pausing the video and see if you can communicate the same insight using far less text. 

What do you think? Based on what you've learned so far, how would you improve this slide? 

Without any context, we don't know why this travel information is meaningful. In addition, this slide groups several ideas together. Does knowing why survey respondents travel belong on the same slide as information on how far in advance people plan their travel? How about the presentation of the data? 

Depending on the audience's needs, perhaps a bar graph would have made this data quicker to grasp. Finally, while the fact that 25 people responded to the survey is good to know, is that as important as the insights being shared? That phrase should be much less visually prominent.
