  • 8 great ways to communicate UX research insights

items.title: Annotating UX Deliverables
items.content:
Why annotate?

The lower-fidelity a design deliverable, the greater the need for annotations. Usability testing with low-fidelity paper prototypes or mid-fidelity wireframes requires at least a degree of imagination from the user. Annotations can help the user visualize the final product and make testing more meaningful.

Even higher-fidelity prototypes can benefit from annotations. There are detailed behaviors and functions that might be burdensome and finicky to represent on every screen. Annotations can communicate contextually important or elaborate details that would be difficult to represent visually. Annotations can also streamline communication with team members, such as developers preparing to implement your designs.

Your goal in writing annotations is so anyone could make sense of your design deliverable without needing to speak with you.

Identify the audience

The first question you should ask before annotating is who is my audience? You should be as familiar as possible with the types of questions your audience will have.

If team members have a lot context for the project, establishing background and contextual reasoning for each screen might be unnecessary. On the other hand, if the bulk of the information is new, you may need to spend more time writing context for your decisions.

Keep in mind, different team members will have different questions. If you are annotating for an audience made up of several roles, you will need to call out the specific role in the annotation.

Be brief

Get your audience to the information they need as easily and quickly as possible. Keep annotations short and to the point. If your design deliverables are clear, focused, and designed with the end audience in mind, heavy annotation shouldn’t be necessary.

  • Avoid design jargon
  • Use active voice for clarity
  • Use simple vocabulary
  • Avoid redundancies

What to annotate

Write a list of scenarios that are important for the audience and project. Ask yourself when will annotations be useful and for who?

Here are a few annotations you might consider making, but the ultimate choice should be based on project needs, and should be applied consistently across every screen.

  • State changes
  • Error states and edge cases
  • Accessibility requirements
  • Interactivity and gestures
  • Hidden content (e.g. dropdown menu, tooltip, modal)
  • Constraints and conditional paths
  • Background research for design decisions
  • Links to additional documentation (design system, research, prototypes)
  • Call to actions
  • Dynamic elements
  • Messaging and prompts

items.title: Presenting UX to Non-Designers
items.content:
Understand your audience

During your time at school, you might get used to presenting to an audience of team members. Your fellow classmates understand the same design terminology and are familiar with the same project parameters.

As a professional, however, you’ll often be tasked with presenting to stakeholders who have little familiarity with the design process. This audience might not instantly recognize the value of the work you’re doing. Convincing them of that value is part of the preparatory work you’ll need to put in when crafting your slides and your presentation.

Knowns and unknowns

Before you prepare to present to an audience that may include non-designers, it’s a good idea to prepare a list of what the audience already knows and what they might expect from you.

Questions you might answer include

  • Who will be present at the next presentation?
  • What do they already know about the current project?
  • How familiar are they with the recent work you’ve been doing?
  • What do they need from you today?
  • What do you need from them?
  • What assumptions might they have?
  • What objections might you have to overcome?
  • What will inspire confidence in your solution?
  • How will you guide them to the next step in the project?

Tips for reaching a non-design audience

In many ways preparing to present to an audience of stakeholders unfamiliar with the design process is similar to preparing any design presentation. You still want to tell a clear narrative, and make sure you rehearse your presentation beforehand until you’re comfortable delivering it.

However, working with a non-design audience has a few important differences from presenting to your immediate teammates.

Practice participatory design

This particular bit advice occurs long before the presentation begins. One excellent way to avoid presenting to a room full of people unfamiliar with the design process is to involve them directly in design workshops, a process known as participatory design.

Participatory designing means involving stakeholders collaboratively on a single problem to come up with possible design solutions. It is a great way to engage the client, bring them into the design process, and learn from their expertise while understanding their business considerations. Meanwhile, the client gets a firsthand view of the design team’s approach to the problem.

Communicate your constraints

If any external factors limited the amount of work your team accomplished during the particular project, it’s important to make stakeholders aware of these limitations. This might include

  • Limited time or budget
  • Technological difficulties
  • Unanticipated discoveries

Explain UX jargon

Below is a small sampling of terms that should be familiar to any UX designer:

  • Affordance
  • Cognitive load
  • Heuristic evaluation
  • Mental model
  • Microinteraction
  • Usability testing

While it’s perfectly fair to include these terms within a design presentation, be prepared to educate your audience on what these terms mean and how they impact the work you’re doing.

Avoid Lorem Ipsum

Lorem Ipsum placeholder text has little value for designers. It’s difficult to present content effectively when you’re not working with the actual approved content.

But Lorem Ipsum is even worse for non-designers. While Lorem Ipsum is theoretically intended to look like real body copy while serving as filler, in practice it’s difficult for clients to focus on the effectiveness of your UI when they’re wondering about the purpose of all these Latin words.

Anticipate questions

While it’s impossible to anticipate every question your audience might ask, do your best to identify likely questions, and work the answers into your presentation.

For example, if you’re demonstrating a prototype meant to test a particular test flow, you might have intentionally not created hotspots for links irrelevant to that task flow. Adding that information to your presentation can help steer your audience away from asking “but what does that button do?”

items.title: 🎬 Presenting UX Designs | Editing Your Story
items.content:
Transcript

 Hello, my name is Anwar and I'm part of the Product Design curriculum team here at Flatiron School. In this series of lectures we'll be discussing presenting UX designs.

Every good design presentation needs to tell a clear story. But how do we edit that story so our audience can connect with it?

Here's a prompt for discussion. Who attends a UX design presentation? What do they want to know?

In an article called Defending UX Design Decisions, UX designer and researcher Chris Kiess says, "if you are going to successfully sell or defend your design, you have to involve those who do not push pixels and make them feel as though they are part of the process."

Without careful editing, even the most interesting story will fail to hold the attention of your audience. As an example, imagine something really exciting happened during your commute this morning, and you can't wait to tell your coworkers about it. Yet when they ask what happened, you begin with, "I grabbed my backpack, wallet and keys. Then I made sure the front door was locked. I walked the five blocks to Broadway, stopping at my favorite coffee cart on the way. My bus wasn't due until 8:35, so I read the news for a bit on my phone." This may accurately describe your commute, but you can bet your coworkers will have tuned out by the time your story gets to the good part.

Similarly, the story of your UX design process requires editing before you present it. There's no question the design process is time consuming and you might be tempted to present the whole thing, step-by-step. But will your audience still be listening by the time you reach the part that impacts them? Instead of reciting what you did, focus on why you took certain steps and how those steps were meaningful.

But if a presentation shouldn't cover every last detail, how should designers shape their story? Here's a five step framework you can use to organize your UX design presentation. Start by introducing the project. Then set context, explain your process, and present your solution. And finally, conclude your presentation and suggest next steps to take. We'll take a closer look at how to use this framework in future videos.

items.title: 🎬 Presenting UX Designs | Introduce the Project
items.content:
Transcript

How should we introduce a UX design presentation?

Begin by reminding the audience why they're here. What is the goal of this presentation? What topics will be discussed? What type of feedback is the audience expected to give?

Next, summarize the scope of work completed during the project. Who worked on the project and what were their roles? When was the work completed? What was the purpose of the project? Explaining the project's purpose is a good opportunity to remind your audience of the information you were initially given. What was on the project brief? What was known about the target user? Establishing a clear background for your presentation will help your audience understand what to expect and how to evaluate the work being presented.

Clearly defining the problem statement is a critical part of any UX design presentation. What problem was the design team trying to solve? Was there a specific pain point facing users? How does this problem impact the business? Plan on referring back frequently to the problem statement. All the work you include in a design presentation should be aimed at finding a solution.

Finally, before moving forward, make sure to identify any testable assumptions you made while getting started on your project. Design projects often change directions as assumptions are confirmed or disproved by testing. Your audience will better understand your project trajectory once you've clearly defined your assumptions and stated your hypothesis – that is, what you believed would happen during usability testing.

items.title: 🎬 Presenting UX Designs | Set Context
items.content:
Transcript

Now that you've introduced your UX design project, it's time to set context so your audience better understands what you were trying to achieve and why.

When starting a UX project, your design team needs to have a pretty clear idea of who you're designing for. When presenting UX design work, make sure your audience has a similarly clear understanding of your target user.

Personas are an important deliverable when setting context in your UX design presentation. Personas reflect your team's understanding of your target audience based on research conducted prior to the launch of the UX design project. Each step of your design process should be presented with your target user's behaviors in mind. Plan on making frequent references to your persona. If your persona is a young front end web developer named Shaima, as seen in this sample persona, then use your presentation to demonstrate how you've solved for Shaima's specific needs and frustrations.

Your target user will inevitably face pain points. What stands between the user and their goal? What impact does each pain point have on the user's journey? How is the business affected if the user can't work past this pain point? While UX design projects often focus on interaction-level pain points, such as a broken or mislabeled interface element causing users to abandon a transaction, some pain points occur at a higher level. Journey-level pain points involve customer dissatisfaction with an overall user journey, while relationship-level pain points describe the souring of a customer's general impression of a brand.

It's not enough to simply name the pain point. Your presentation should also include a detailed description of when the user encounters the frustration. Assuming the pain point occurs at an interaction level, does it happen at a certain moment in the user journey? Is it specific to the user's device? For example, mobile users might be experiencing the pain point while tablet users don't. What about external factors from the user's environment that might impact the experience, such as working in a noisy coffee shop, or using the product in a dark room late at night?Or are there barriers that prevent users with a permanent, situational, or temporary disability from reaching their goal?

Now it's time for discussion. What if your product is not a website or mobile app? Think about a digital user interface in a car's dashboard, for example. When presenting your designs, would setting the context be the same or different? In what ways?

items.title: 🎬 Presenting UX Designs | Explain Your Process
items.content:
Transcript

Once you've introduced your project and set the context for your audience, you're ready to explain your design process. But doing so is not as simple as just describing everything you did, step-by-step.

Your audience wants to hear what you learned, not what you did. In other words, you're not here to present a complete list of the tasks you accomplished. You're here to present insights gained from performing those tasks in a way that helps stakeholders better understand the needs of target users.

Hopefully you recognize some variation of this graphic. You should be aware that design is an iterative process that includes empathizing, defining, ideating, prototyping, and testing. But here's the thing: your UX design presentation audience doesn't really care. You might sometimes refer to the design process to justify a particular experiment. We needed to prototype this specific feature to learn this information about our users. But it's not necessary to provide exhaustive detail on every step of the process–especially if a particular step didn't impact the project outcome.

When thinking about what aspects of your design process to include, highlight the parts that accomplish one or more of the following. The task you're presenting might reveal insights about your user, allowing stakeholders to better understand the user's needs and motivations. Or maybe you've uncovered a chance to meet business goals or do something better than the competition. A particular test might've confirmed an earlier assumption, or perhaps it disproved an assumption and forced your team to change directions. Above all, think about each step you include as something intended to inspire confidence in your design solution. If an experiment you ran or a deliverable you created doesn't do any of the above, it's best to leave it out of your presentation.

For example, suppose you conducted an open card sort. When presenting the results, highlight the issues users were having with the existing information architecture that made the card sort necessary. While you might briefly explain how the card sort workshop was executed, you likely wouldn't show a spreadsheet of the workshop results, since spreadsheets are not easy for presentation audiences to understand. Instead focus on the results of the card sort. Do you better understand your user's mental model for how your content is organized? Was a preexisting hypothesis confirmed or invalidated? What should happen next based on the results?

Or if you tested a paper prototype, your setup should focus on why low fidelity made sense at this stage, as well as your hypothesis and what you hoped to learn. Then highlight the results of your usability tests, which could include direct quotes or videos. Finally, conclude with takeaways and present the impact the results of the test had on the project direction moving forward.

items.title: 🎬 Presenting UX Designs | Present Your Solution
items.content:
Transcript

Now let's take a look at presenting your UX design solution.

You've already seen this slide labeled "who is your user", but that's no accident. When presenting your solution, it's critical to remind your audience that your solution was created in response to specific pain points experienced by a specific target user within a specific context.

Your audience is eager to learn whether your project was successful. But how do UX designers measure success? By reminding their audience of the original problem statement and demonstrating that the work never lost sight of that problem. This is your chance to convince stakeholders that your work met project objectives and sought answers to key questions facing the business.

When presenting a completed prototype, demonstrate screens, features, and interactions that are relevant to the problem you were trying to solve. Prepare your audience by defining the scope of the prototype and stating which user flow your demonstration will concentrate on. That way, the discussion doesn't get derailed and your viewers don't focus on elements you haven't built or are irrelevant to the current conversation.

When presenting your solution, explain how it benefits your target persona. You designed for a specific user facing specific obstacles in a specific context. Was your solution helpful? Are target users now better equipped to overcome pain points? Citing evidence is an effective way to show, rather than tell, the impact of your solution. You might include data highlighting the effectiveness of your new design versus the old design, as well as quotes from users or videos from usability tests.

If your audience consists of stakeholders, they'll be anxious to know how your solution increases revenue or otherwise meets business needs. As you remove obstacles facing the user, the business should be able to meet more of its goals. Highlight the ways your solution benefits the business and keep the amount of design or technical jargon in your presentation to a minimum. If you must include a technical term, plan on defining it.

items.title: 🎬 Presenting UX Designs | Conclusion
items.content:
Transcript

How should we conclude a UX design presentation? Let's take a look.

The conclusion to your UX design presentation should have three goals. You'll want to reflect on what you've accomplished and learned, provide recommendations for next steps, and seek audience feedback.

In your conclusion, briefly remind your audience of your project's most important accomplishments and what you learned by conducting the project. As you reflect on what you've learned, it's okay to admit the shortcomings of the project or to describe what you do differently next time.

Based on the outcome of this project, what steps should follow next? Your suggestions for next steps will depend on the takeaways from this project. It's possible you'll recommend conducting more research, or building additional prototypes to run additional usability tests. On the other hand, perhaps your project is ready to move forward to a higher-fidelity design or development stage.

At the beginning of the presentation, you set expectations for audience feedback. During the conclusion, refer back to those same expectations. Rather than ending with a simple, "well, what do you think?", ask your audience questions based on the kinds of feedback you need. You might check whether they support the way you've simplified the user flow, whether your solution is consistent with other brand experiences, or whether they support your vision for next steps in the design process.

Now it's time for discussion. What might be a good way to handle stakeholder feedback that contradicts what you've learned from target users? What about feedback that falls outside the scope or goals of the project?

items.title: Annotations for Accessibility
items.content:
Accessibility through collaboration

True web accessibility only happens when every member of the product team is equally invested in making sure web content is accessible to users with all sorts of permanent, temporary, and situational disabilities.

In addition, no product can be considered truly accessible unless user testing involves disabled users.

So the goal of annotating your UI designs for accessibility isn’t proscriptive solutions. It’s to start a conversation with developers about the best way to build accessible interfaces, and to make sure accessibility doesn’t get overlooked during development.

When to annotate for accessibility

When it comes time to prepare a document for handoff to developers, your designs ideally won’t need a ton of accessibility-specific annotations. To get to a place where few annotations are necessary, your team needs two things:

  • An equal commitment to accessibility from both designers and developers. If the entire product team factors in accessibility needs from day one, and everyone is equally committed to building an accessible product,accessibility reminders can be kept to a minimum. If your development team is used to building accessible interfaces, allow them leeway to solve for accessibility themselves, rather than dictating every last detail.
  • A design system that prioritizes accessible solutions. If your design system features accessible minimum type sizes and color combinations, for example, both designers and developers will be used to implementing accessible choices automatically.

When implementing your designs, developers can review their code using tools like The A11y Project’s Reviewing a design for accessibility checklist.

However, there are a few situations where an accessible solution might not be completely obvious. Let’s review a few of those cases.

Complex images

If your development team is used to supporting disabled users, you shouldn’t need to remind them to create useful alt descriptions for images. However, for more complex images such as a chart, it’s worth discussing alt description strategies, or suggesting descriptions in your annotations.

Focus states

For keyboard-only users, operating an interface without focus indicators would be like operating a mouse with no cursor. You’d never know what you’re pressing.

Focus indicators let users know which interface element is currently selected, which is critical information for screen reader users and users with motor skills disabilities making it difficult to control a mouse.

When designing interaction states for interface elements such as buttons, don’t forget to design an obvious focus state. And as pointed out in Caitlin Geier’s Give Your Site Some Focus! Tips for Designing Useful and Usable Focus Indicators, it’s not good enough to rely on the browser’s default focus indicators. Focus indicators aren’t implemented consistently from browser to browser, and the default setting isn’t necessarily visually obvious.

Unlabeled interface elements

In most cases, designers should work to make interface elements as obvious as possible. In a bottom navigation in a mobile application, for example, a combination of recognizable icons and clear interface labels will help users understand the purpose of each button.

At times, however, you might encounter situations where unlabeled interface elements make sense.

In the above mockup, shoppers can toggle between a choice of red, yellow, and black socks by tapping colored circular buttons. While this interface might make sense to visual users, it’s critical that developers name the buttons so users of screen readers can still make sense of them. Here, the designer has provided alternate labels such as “view socks in yellow” that developers can implement, most likely using the aria-label attribute.

Alternatives for complex gestures

WCAG Success Criterion 2.5.1: Pointer Gestures states that simple alternatives must be provided for interactions activated by complex gestures. When an interaction requires more than a simple touch, such as

  • Asking the user to use multiple fingers
  • Requiring the user to swipe along a specific path

Designers and developers should work together to create a simpler alternative gesture. Users with motor skills disabilities will struggle to perform the more complex gestures, and users with cognitive disabilities might have trouble remembering the complex action.

Note that the criterion makes exceptions for both essential gestures (drawing a signature with your finger on a mobile device to complete a form) and for gestures specific to the operating system (swipe right to see additional content).

In the above wireframe, users may swipe from right to left to archive an email. However, the designer has provided two simpler interactions as an alternative: users may press and hold the email to bring up a toolbar that offers the opportunity to archive the email with a simple tap. Or, users may tap the email to view it in detail, then tap the Archive icon in the top toolbar.

items.title: Creating a UI Style Guide
items.content:
Design Systems vs Style Guides

A design system is a set of rules that guide the design of a web site, an app, or a suite of digital products. Design systems help create predictable experiences for users, and help designers and developers work more efficiently and build interfaces consistent with an organization’s visual brand without wasting time exploring design problems that have been solved already.

A repository of design systems can be found at Design Systems Repo. Some of the more famous examples found here include

  • Spectrum, design system for Adobe
  • Polaris, design system for Shopify
  • United States Web Design System, for US government websites

A style guide tends to be just one portion of a design system. While a design system might include brand guidelines, accessibility guidelines, voice and tone guidelines, and code snippets, a style guide tends to keep its focus on UI components.

While the specifics of a style guide might vary, typically style guides include documentation on implementing the following:

  • color
  • typography
  • spacing
  • imagery
  • motion

Color

Color documentation within a style guide should specify color palette, including dominant, secondary, and accent colors. In addition, style guide documentation should also include

  • Hexadecimal values. Make your colors easier for developers to implement by providing hexadecimal color codes. If your brand’s primary orange color is #cc6600, for example, let developers easily locate and copy this information.
  • Rules for implementation. Demonstrate how colors reinforce meaning and are applied to interactive elements.
  • Accessible color combinations. provide color rules that dictate which combination of colors will meet WCAG Color Contrast requirements.

Typography

In addition to demonstrating your typefaces of choice, typographic rules within a style guide should include

  • Rules for implementation. demonstrate how your typography is applied to headings, body copy, captions, code snippets, and labeling interface elements.
  • Type scale. Shopify’s Polaris offers guidance for designers and developers on scaling type to create visual hierarchy on both small and large displays.
  • Spacing. While spacing between elements will be covered in a separate section, rules for typographic spacing such as leading and space separating paragraphs should be covered in your typographic rules.

Spacing

Style guide rules within design systems tend to specify spacing units using multiples of either 4 or 8. This is an intentional choice.

  • Most screen resolutions are divisible by four
  • Using an even number makes it easier to translate your design to screens with higher pixel densities

Imagery

Imagery guidelines within a style guide sometimes include rules for choosing and incorporating photographic imagery, especially for use across devices. More common, however, are rules regarding icons and illustrations.

  • Icons. Will your icons use an external source, such as FontAwesome? Or does your brand include its own custom icons?

    More importantly, how will users recognize the meaning of the icons you’re using?

  • Illustrations. Does your brand allow for illustrations? If so, how will you maintain a consistent style? Are there situations that are appropriate (or inappropriate) for using illustrations?

Motion

“Motion brings meaning and a sense of life to the experience. It should be purposeful, intuitive, and seamless. It should help users be more productive and never slow them down.” – Adobe Spectrum motion guidelines

If your product uses motion, your style guide should offer guidance on how to implement motion meaningfully, without distracting the user, causing accessibility issues, or slowing the web page performance down.

items.title: 🎬 Presenting UI Designs | Plan Your Presentation
items.content:
Transcript

Hello, My name is Anwar and I'm part of the Product Design curriculum team here at Flatiron School. In this series of lectures we'll be discussing presenting UI designs. Let's begin by discussing how to plan your presentation.

UI designer Tess Gadd says don't present your work like a painting, present it like a building. After all, good architects don't make arbitrary choices. When presenting the designs for a building, they'll start from the blueprints and focus on practical considerations like what materials the building is made from, where the morning and afternoon sun will hit, or how many people can fit on each floor before it becomes a fire hazard. You'll want to approach presenting UI the same way, by focusing on the impact each design choice will have.

As you're planning your presentation, make sure you know who's in your audience. When presenting to stakeholders–in other words, anyone who has an interest in your project and influence over your decision-making–you'll need to speak the language of business. Stakeholders might not know much about the design process, so it's your responsibility to connect your explanation of that process to their product division and business goals.

If you're instead presenting to teammates, keep their strengths and interests in mind. Developers, for example, will be interested in the technological feasibility, performance, and accessibility of your solution.

Like any design presentation, your UI design presentation should tell a cohesive story, one that begins with the problem you were solving for and ends with the benefits your designs have for both users and the business.

Now it's time for discussion. What if your audience contains both stakeholders and teammates? What strategies could help your presentation meet the needs of both groups?

items.title: 🎬 Presenting UI Designs | Prepare Your Slides
items.content:
Transcript

Now let's discuss preparing your UI design presentation slides.

First of all, you'll need to select the design deliverables that add meaning to your story. Keep in mind that just because you completed a deliverable doesn't mean it automatically belongs in your presentation. With each deliverable, ask yourself, will my audience understand why this deliverable is relevant to the problem I'm trying to solve? Did this help me test the effectiveness of my solution with target users? Is this moving my story towards a meaningful conclusion? If not, leave it out.

Once you've decided what imagery to include, think about how to best present it. In the image on screen, we see a closeup of a dropdown navigation being interacted with, illustrating that it's not always necessary to include a screenshot of the entire layout. Especially when your work focuses on one small part of the interface.

When demonstrating a specific improvement to a user interface, it often helps to show the old and improved version side-by-side. While the designer of the mobile interface on screen has separated the most critical link visually to indicate its importance, without comparing this change to the previous design, the impact of the improvement might be hard to grasp.

You can use this technique of comparing old and improved versions to demonstrate accessibility improvements to your interface as well. For example, interface elements that are too small or too close together can cause issues for users with motor skills disabilities. The image on screen visualizes the benefits of adjusting an interface to meet the WCAG target size recommendation.

Careless slide design can make even the most polished UI designs look underwhelming or ineffective. The principles of visual hierarchy, white space, grid, and type hierarchy matter just as much when designing slides as they do when creating a user interface.

A consistent layout from slide to slide reduces cognitive load for viewers and keeps attention focused on the most important content.

You can additionally reduce cognitive load by sticking to one idea per slide. Include just enough words, imagery, and data on each slide to get a single, memorable point across.

Be cautious about over-designing your slides. If viewers are paying more attention to the design of your slide than the actual content, that's a problem.

Finally, respect the client's style guide while designing your slides. Keep the color, type, spacing, and iconography you apply to each slide consistent with the existing style guide or design system. If your client doesn't have one, create your own rough style guide and stick to it.

items.title: 🎬 Presenting UI Designs | Describing Your Design
items.content:
Transcript

Once your presentation slides are ready, how do you describe your design choices to an audience? Let's take a look.

In his 2015 textbook Articulating Design Decisions, product designer and author Tom Greever says that one of the best ways to make a case for your designs is to directly connect it to the needs of the business. Which is a reminder that you didn't make your UI design decisions arbitrarily, but instead to enhance usability and increase the chances of a successful interaction with your client's product.

UI designers don't make subjective choices. It's not a question of which color looks better or which typefaces pair the nicest. You've made objective decisions meant to satisfy specific criteria. And that objective reasoning is what you need to convey when presenting your designs. There are four key reasons a design decision might be made: to meet a business need, to help users reach a goal, to apply research findings, or because of a limitation or requirement impacting the project.

Stakeholders are anxious to hear how your solution meets business needs. In the example on screen, making the price of the package being offered bold, visually prominent, and above the fold increased the number of signups and inquiries received by the business. If changes such as making an interface element more prominent, increasing white space, or improving wording are designed to bring more conversions, highlight this reasoning during your presentation.

Call attention to interface design solutions that have been guided by your client's existing design system or style guide, or are consistent with the brand's established identity. What if your client doesn't have an existing design system, style guide, or brand identity? That's a tough situation for a UI designer. When presenting your designs, emphasize the need for consistency from screen to screen in terms of color, typography, spacing, motion, voice and tone, and interface element design. By creating and applying a consistent visual language, you can help your client begin to establish their brand.

Another way to justify UI design decisions is to describe how your solution benefits the user. Does your design help users figure out where they are, how to get around, and what navigation options they currently have? Does it inspire users to take action or move them closer towards a goal?

Sometimes business needs align with user goals. When your UI improvements relieve user pain points within a checkout flow, the user has a successful experience and business profits increase.

Highlight any consideration your UI design gives for the user's context. In the image on screen, we see a smartwatch app intended to be used while jogging. Think about what a user might need before, during, and after their run. What features matter most to the user? What might contribute to a successful run? What factors might make the app difficult to use? Might the screen be difficult to see in bright sunlight, or while jogging after dark? Should any features be muted so they don't distract or annoy the user during their run?

Does your solution make use of a familiar design pattern? Implementing common design patterns reduces cognitive load for the user and makes your interface feel familiar. Depending on the popularity of the pattern, your stakeholders might not be familiar with it, so be prepared to list its benefits and provide relevant examples while explaining your process for choosing the pattern. What rules guidance implementation? How did you know it was the right choice for your stakeholder's product?

If you're applying data-driven decisions to your interface design, make that clear during your presentation. Your decision might be motivated by primary research you conducted yourself, such as analytics suggesting users commonly bail out at a specific point in a flow. Or you might use secondary research gathered by people outside your organization, such as online articles written by subject matter experts. You might also understand your target audience's preferences thanks to usability testing conducted by your team.

When describing or defending your design choices, you might also remind your audience of time, budget, and technology constraints. The sky, isn't always the limit when creating an interface. Sometimes a proposed solution can't be achieved within the project's timeline or budget, or it might be difficult for the development team to implement.

Sometimes proposed designs need to be adjusted to work with established web development standards, such as semantic HTML. Other changes might be motivated by reviewing WCAG accessibility requirements or by running usability tests with disabled users. Your presentation should highlight any design solution that enables your stakeholder's product to comply with existing standards.

Now it's time for discussion. Does a designer's personal preference matter in a UI design presentation? Or is it all about user goals and business needs?

items.title: 🎬 Presenting UI Designs | Shaping and Receiving Feedback
items.content:
Transcript

Finally, let's discuss shaping and receiving feedback from your audience.

Presenting UI design can be a unique challenge because audiences often give subjective feedback. When the focus is on whether a participant likes or dislikes certain color or type face choices, or the size or placement of interface elements, a meeting can quickly get derailed. How can we shift the discussion away from personal preferences and towards the objective impact each design decision has?

One of the most effective methods of receiving objective feedback is to schedule regular feedback sessions with relevant stakeholders at each step of the design process. If you only present completed designs your audience hasn't encountered before, they might not understand what motivated your design decisions. Instead, let stakeholders witness why and how your designs evolve over time. This also allows them the opportunity to provide feedback early.

Towards the beginning of your presentation, while reminding your audience of the project goal and the problem you were trying to solve, set clear expectations on the type of feedback you're hoping to receive. Maybe you're looking to hear about the success of the overall flow, or about specific interactions, or subtle changes to microcopy. Alert your audience to your feedback needs early so they know what to look for while listening to your presentation.

When designing your slides, you'll want to apply a consistent grid, allow for generous white space, and use principles of visual hierarchy to direct attention to the most important elements. While we've made this point already, it's worth repeating, as clean, professional slide design boosts your audience's confidence in you and keeps them from getting distracted. Researchers call this the Aesthetic Usability Effect. Users often perceive aesthetically pleasing design as design that's more usable.

Here's an important rule. Keep Lorem Ipsum out of your presentations. You shouldn't be designing with Lorem Ipsum in the first place, since your decision should support actual content rather than placeholder text. In a design presentation, Lorem Ipsum gives slides an amateur feel. Your stakeholders might also start wondering about all that Latin text, rather than concentrating on your interface design.

Finally, be sure to conclude your presentation memorably. Ending by saying, "so, what do you think?" is not all that effective. Your final slides should refer back to the original problem you were trying to solve, provide recommended next steps, and summarize lessons learned during the project. In addition, your conclusion is a good chance to remind your audience of the feedback you're seeking. Try asking your audience a specific question related to your project goals, such as "do you think this improved flow will lead to more signups?"

In product designer Finna Wang's portfolio, she concludes her case study for her design work on the Jambb social media platform with lessons learned from the project, a recommendation for an additional feature, and a business opportunity for the Jambb application to integrate videos from additional social media services. In addition to asking stakeholders to evaluate the success of the design project, Wang could also spark additional discussion from her audience with these three thoughtful topics.

Now let's talk about receiving feedback from your audience. In the words of UI and UX designer Jeremiah Lam, scheduling regular feedback sessions helps cultivate a culture where feedback and opinions are respected and seen as part of the design process.

When receiving feedback, resist the urge to interrupt and defend your designs. Take notes and hear the participant out fully. Before you respond, ask clarifying questions about the feedback you receive. Keep your questions goal oriented. For example, if a stakeholder suggests a color, typography, or spacing change on a landing page, you might ask how the change would draw more attention to the Call To Action.

When listening to feedback, consider where the participant is coming from. Stakeholders will naturally be most concerned with whether your designs meet business objectives. Designers, on the other hand, will offer critiques to help strengthen your designs. Developers will comment on the feasibility and any possible implementation issues. And project managers might ask how the solution fits within the project’s requirements and scope.

If you need to defend a design decision, cite evidence that supports your point of view. This might include a guiding design principle, a reference to the client's design system or style guide, or data from research or usability testing. Sometimes you'll need additional time to evaluate feedback. While many critiques are valuable, some will be irrelevant to the project goals or unrealistic to implement. Rather than responding on the spot, it's okay to ask for time to think things over. Your audience will be glad to hear their feedback is being considered. And you can use the extra time to work out whether to implement the change or tactfully push back against it.
